solution: **1) Which equation would you use to calculate Momentum?** Use linear momentum $p=mv$. --- **2) What is the next step?** Write the **conservation of linear momentum** for the short impact (take + to the right). --- **3) What is the momentum of the system before impact?** $ p_i=m_s v_{s, i}+m_p v_{p, i} =2(30)+0.09(5)=60+0.45=60.45 \text{kg\cdotm/s}.$--- **4) What is the momentum equation for after impact?**$m_s v_{s, f}+m_p v_{p, f}=p_i \Rightarrow\quad 2v_{s, f}+0.09v_{p, f}=60.45.$--- **5) Which equation would you use to find the coefficient of restitution for the impact?** Use the COR (1-D):$e=\frac{\text{speed of separation}}{\text{speed of approach}} =\frac{v_{p, f}-v_{s, f}}{, v_{s, i}-v_{p, i},}.$--- **6) Substitute the given numbers into the COR relation.**$v_{p, f}-v_{s, f} =e,(v_{s, i}-v_{p, i}) =0.7(30-5)=17.5.$--- **7) What is the next step?** Express one unknown in terms of the other:$v_{p, f}=v_{s, f}+17.5.$--- **8) What are we left with from the COR relation?** The single relation above, to be used with momentum:$\boxed{, v_{p, f}=v_{s, f}+17.5, }.$--- **9) How do you solve for the velocity of the puck after impact?** Substitute$v_{p,f}=v_{s,f}+17.5$into$2v_{s,f}+0.09v_{p,f}=60.45$and solve.$2v_{s, f}+0.09(v_{s, f}+17.5)=60.45 \Rightarrow 2.09v_{s, f}=58.875 \Rightarrow v_{s, f}\approx 28.17 \text{m/s}.$v_{p, f}=v_{s, f}+17.5\approx 45.67 \text{m/s}.$--- **10) What is the velocity of the puck after impact?**$\boxed{v_{p, f}\approx 45.7 \text{m/s (forward)}}.$--- **11) What is the final Momentum of the puck?**$p_{p, f}=m_p v_{p, f}=0.09(45.67)\approx \boxed{4.11 \text{kg\cdotm/s (forward)}}.$

full_question: A hockey stick travelling forward at $30 \mathrm{m/s}$ strikes a puck travelling forward at $5 \mathrm{m/s}$. The stick has mass $2 \mathrm{kg}$, the puck has mass $0.09 \mathrm{kg}$, and the coefficient of restitution is $e=0.7$. What is the final momentum of the puck?
sub_question: What is the final Momentum of the puck?
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to calculate Momentum?** Use linear momentum $p=mv$. --- **2) What is the next step?** Write the **conservation of linear momentum** for the short impact (take + to the right). --- **3) What is the momentum of the system before impact?** $ p_i=m_s v_{s, i}+m_p v_{p, i} =2(30)+0.09(5)=60+0.45=60.45 \text{kg\cdotm/s}.$--- **4) What is the momentum equation for after impact?**$m_s v_{s, f}+m_p v_{p, f}=p_i \Rightarrow\quad 2v_{s, f}+0.09v_{p, f}=60.45.$--- **5) Which equation would you use to find the coefficient of restitution for the impact?** Use the COR (1-D):$e=\frac{\text{speed of separation}}{\text{speed of approach}} =\frac{v_{p, f}-v_{s, f}}{, v_{s, i}-v_{p, i},}.$--- **6) Substitute the given numbers into the COR relation.**$v_{p, f}-v_{s, f} =e,(v_{s, i}-v_{p, i}) =0.7(30-5)=17.5.$--- **7) What is the next step?** Express one unknown in terms of the other:$v_{p, f}=v_{s, f}+17.5.$--- **8) What are we left with from the COR relation?** The single relation above, to be used with momentum:$\boxed{, v_{p, f}=v_{s, f}+17.5, }.$--- **9) How do you solve for the velocity of the puck after impact?** Substitute$v_{p,f}=v_{s,f}+17.5$into$2v_{s,f}+0.09v_{p,f}=60.45$and solve.$2v_{s, f}+0.09(v_{s, f}+17.5)=60.45 \Rightarrow 2.09v_{s, f}=58.875 \Rightarrow v_{s, f}\approx 28.17 \text{m/s}.$v_{p, f}=v_{s, f}+17.5\approx 45.67 \text{m/s}.$--- **10) What is the velocity of the puck after impact?**$\boxed{v_{p, f}\approx 45.7 \text{m/s (forward)}}.$--- **11) What is the final Momentum of the puck?**$p_{p, f}=m_p v_{p, f}=0.09(45.67)\approx \boxed{4.11 \text{kg\cdotm/s (forward)}}.$

full_question: What is the magnitude of the normal force of a 28 kg block on a level surface?
sub_question: What is the normal force?
option_1: the force of gravity acting on the object
option_2: the force exerted by the resting surface on the object
option_3: the force the object exerts on the resting surface
option_4: the force along the path of motion
feedback_1: Incorrect that s the object s weight ($W=mg$), not the normal force.
feedback_2: Correct the normal is the force the surface exerts on the object, perpendicular to the surface.
feedback_3: Not quite that s the equal-and-opposite reaction the object exerts on the surface (Newton s 3rd law).
feedback_4: Incorrect this refers to a tangential force along the motion path, not the normal.
solution: **1) What is the normal force?** The surface s contact force on the block, acting perpendicular to the surface (upward on a level surface). --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** Use vertical equilibrium: $\sum F_y=0 ;\Rightarrow; N - mg = 0$. --- **3) What is the value of $\alpha$?** $\alpha = 0^\circ$ for a level surface. --- **4) The normal force of a 28 kg block on a level surface is ** $N = mg = (28 \text{kg})(9.8 \text{m/s}^2) = 274.4 \text{N};$ (upward).

full_question: What force do we need to apply to a 25 kg object in order to overcome the force of friction if the coefficient of friction is 0.5?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?
feedback_1: Incorrect that s the component of weight along an incline, not the friction law.
feedback_2: Correct friction magnitude is $F_f=\mu N$.
feedback_3: Incorrect missing the normal force (and mass).
feedback_4: Incorrect Newton s 2nd-law form; not the friction formula.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N$ --- **2) What is the value of $\mu$?** $\mu = 0.5$ --- **3) What is the normal force?** The surface s contact force on the object, perpendicular to the surface. --- **4) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N=mg\cos\alpha$ --- **5) What is the value of $\alpha$?** $\alpha=0^\circ$ (level surface) --- **6) What is the normal force of a 25 kg block on a level surface?** $N = mg = (25)(9.8)=245 \text{N}$ (upward) --- **7) What is the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N=0.5\times 245=122.5 \text{N}$ --- **8) What force do we need to apply to overcome friction?** To just start motion: $F_{\text{apply}}\ge F_f \Rightarrow \boxed{F_{\text{apply}}\gtrsim 122.5 \text{N}}$

full_question: An object is sitting on a level surface. Given the force of friction on a 15 kg object is 130 N, what is the coefficient of friction?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?
feedback_1: Incorrect component of weight along an incline, not friction law.
feedback_2: Correct friction magnitude is $F_f=\mu N$.
feedback_4: Incorrect Newton s 2nd law form; not the friction formula.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N$ --- **2) What is the normal force?** The surface s contact force on the object, perpendicular to the surface. --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N=mg\cos\alpha$ --- **4) What is the value of $\alpha$?** $\alpha=0^\circ$ (level surface) --- **5) What is the normal force of a 15 kg block on a level surface?** $N=mg=(15)(9.8)=147 \text{N}$ --- **6) Which equation would you use to find $\mu$?** $\mu=\dfrac{F_f}{N}$ --- **7) An object is sitting on a level surface. Given the force of friction on a 15 kg object is $130 \mathrm{N}$, what is the coefficient of friction?** $\mu=\dfrac{130}{147}\approx \boxed{0.884}$ (dimensionless)

full_question: An object is sitting on an incline, 30 to the horizontal. Given the force of friction on a 30 kg object is 100 N, what is the coefficient of friction?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?
feedback_1: Incorrect that s the component of weight along the slope, not the friction law.
feedback_2: Correct friction magnitude is $F_f=\mu N$.
feedback_3: Incorrect missing the normal force $N$ (and mass).
feedback_4: Incorrect Newton s 2nd law form, not the friction formula.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N$ (limiting static friction) --- **2) What is the normal force?** The surface s contact force on the object, perpendicular to the surface. --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N=mg\cos\alpha$ --- **4) What is the value of $\alpha$?** $\alpha=30^\circ$ --- **5) What is the normal force of a 30 kg block on the incline?** $N=(30)(9.8)\cos 30^\circ \approx 254.6 \text{N}$ --- **6) Which equation would you use to find $\mu$?** $\mu=\dfrac{F_f}{N}$ --- **7) An object is sitting on an incline, $30^\circ$ to the horizontal. What is the coefficient of friction?** For equilibrium on the incline, $F_f=mg\sin\alpha$, so $\displaystyle \mu=\frac{F_f}{N}=\frac{mg\sin\alpha}{mg\cos\alpha}=\tan\alpha=\tan 30^\circ\approx \boxed{0.577},.$

full_question: A 10 kg object is sitting on an incline of 50 . What is the minimum coefficient of friction needed to prevent the object from sliding down the incline?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?
feedback_1: Incorrect that s the downslope component of weight.
feedback_2: Correct friction magnitude is $F_f=\mu N$.
feedback_4: Incorrect Newton s 2nd-law form, not the friction law.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N$ --- **2) What is the normal force?** The surface s contact force on the object, perpendicular to the surface. --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N=mg\cos\alpha$ --- **4) What is the value of $\alpha$?** $\alpha=50^\circ$ --- **5) What is the normal force of a 10 kg block on the incline?** $N=(10)(9.8)\cos 50^\circ\approx 62.99 \text{N}$ --- **6) What is the force pulling the object down the incline (i.e., caused by gravity)?** $F_\parallel=mg\sin\alpha=(10)(9.8)\sin 50^\circ\approx 75.07 \text{N}$ --- **7) What is the relationship between the force pulling the object down the incline and the force of friction if the object is to rest?** At the threshold of motion: $F_f=F_\parallel$ (along the plane). --- **8) What is the force of friction?** $F_f=F_\parallel\approx 75.07 \text{N}$ (upslope) --- **9) Which equation would you use to find $\mu$?** $\mu=\dfrac{F_f}{N}$ --- **10) What is the minimum coefficient of friction needed to prevent the object from sliding down the incline?** $\mu_{\min}=\dfrac{F_\parallel}{N}=\dfrac{mg\sin\alpha}{mg\cos\alpha}=\tan\alpha=\tan 50^\circ\approx \boxed{1.19}$ (dimensionless)

full_question: A car traveling at 20 m/s enters a curve of 100 m radius with a radial acceleration of $4 m/s^2$. If the mass of the car is 700 kg, what is the frictional force required to keep it on the curve?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force caused by the radial acceleration?
feedback_1: Incorrect that s the friction law, not centripetal force.
feedback_2: Correct centripetal force is $F=ma_r$.
feedback_3: Incorrect kinetic energy, not a force.
feedback_4: Incorrect work over time (power), wrong dimensions.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force caused by the radial acceleration?** $F_c = m a_r$ --- **2) What is the force caused by the radial acceleration?** $F_c = (700)(4) = 2800 \text{N}$ --- **3) What is the frictional force required to keep it on the curve?** Since static friction provides the centripetal force on a flat curve, $F_{\text{fric}} = F_c = \boxed{2800 \text{N (toward the center)}}$.

sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force of friction between the road and the car tires?
feedback_1: Not for level curves; that s the downslope component on an incline.
feedback_2: Correct: limiting friction is $F_f=\mu N$.
feedback_4: Generic net-force form; not the friction law.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force of friction between the road and the car tires?** $F_f=\mu N$ --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N=mg$ --- **3) What is the value of the normal force?** $N=(700)(9.8)=6860 \text{N}$ --- **4) What is the value of the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N=0.6\times 6860=4116 \text{N}$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the radial (centripetal) acceleration that can be achieved by the car against this force?** $a_r=\dfrac{F_f}{m}$ --- **6) What is the value of $a_r$?** $a_r=\dfrac{4116}{700}=5.88 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **7) Which equation would you use to calculate the angular velocity given $a_r$?** $a_r=\omega^2 r;\Rightarrow;\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}$ --- **8) What is the value of the angular velocity?** $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{5.88}{100}}=\sqrt{0.0588}\approx 0.242 \text{rad/s}$ --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the linear velocity of the car given the angular velocity?** $v=\omega r$ --- **10)Which equation would you use to find the force caused by the radial acceleration?** $F_c=m a_r$ --- **11) What is the maximum velocity the car can achieve without sliding off the road?** $v_{\max}=\omega r=0.242\times 100\approx \boxed{24.25 \text{m/s}}$

full_question: A car traveling at 20 m/s enters a curve of 100 m radius with a radial acceleration of 4 m/s^2. If the mass of the car is 700 kg, and the curve is banked $15^\circ$, what is the frictional force required to keep the car on the curve ($\mu=0.6$)?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force caused by the radial acceleration?
feedback_1: Correct centripetal (radial) force is $F=ma_r$.
feedback_2: Incorrect kinetic-energy form (and missing $v^2$), not a force.
feedback_3: Incorrect work over time (power), wrong dimensions.
feedback_4: Incorrect friction law, not centripetal force.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force caused by the radial acceleration?** $F_c = m a_r$ --- **2) What is the force caused by the radial acceleration?** $F_c = (700)(4) = 2800 \text{N}$ --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the component of the radial acceleration that causes the car to slide up the bank?** $a_{r, \parallel}^{\text{(up bank)}} = a_r \cos\alpha$ --- **4) What is the magnitude of the component of the radial acceleration that causes the car to slide up the bank?** $a_{r, \parallel}^{\text{(up bank)}} = 4\cos 15^\circ \approx 3.86 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the component of the gravitational force pulling the car down the bank?** $F_{g, \parallel} = mg\sin\alpha$ --- **6) What is the magnitude of the component of the gravitational force pulling the car down the bank?** $F_{g, \parallel} = (700)(9.8)\sin 15^\circ \approx 1775.5 \text{N}$ --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the magnitude of the force causing the car to slide off the road?** $F_{\text{cause}} = (m a_r \cos\alpha) - (mg\sin\alpha)$ --- **8) What is the magnitude of the force causing the car to slide off the road?** $F_{\text{cause}} = (700)(4)\cos 15^\circ - 700(9.8)\sin 15^\circ \approx 2704.6 - 1775.5 \approx 929.1 \text{N}$ --- **9) What is the frictional force required to keep the car on the curve?** $F_{\text{fric}} = F_{\text{cause}} \approx \boxed{9.29\times 10^2 \text{N}}$ (directed **down the bank**, toward the center)

full_question: A car traveling at 20 m/s enters a curve of 100 m radius with a radial acceleration of 4 m/s^2. If the mass of the car is 700 kg, and the curve is banked $15^\circ$, what is the frictional force required to keep the car on the curve ($\mu=0.6$)?
sub_question: What is the force caused by the radial acceleration?

solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the force caused by the radial acceleration?** $F_c = m a_r$ --- **2) What is the force caused by the radial acceleration?** $F_c = (700)(4) = 2800 \text{N}$ --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the component of the radial acceleration that causes the car to slide up the bank?** $a_{r, \parallel}^{\text{(up bank)}} = a_r \cos\alpha$ --- **4) What is the magnitude of the component of the radial acceleration that causes the car to slide up the bank?** $a_{r, \parallel}^{\text{(up bank)}} = 4\cos 15^\circ \approx 3.86 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the component of the gravitational force pulling the car down the bank?** $F_{g, \parallel} = mg\sin\alpha$ --- **6) What is the magnitude of the component of the gravitational force pulling the car down the bank?** $F_{g, \parallel} = (700)(9.8)\sin 15^\circ \approx 1775.5 \text{N}$ --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the magnitude of the force causing the car to slide off the road?** $F_{\text{cause}} = (m a_r \cos\alpha) - (mg\sin\alpha)$ --- **8) What is the magnitude of the force causing the car to slide off the road?** $F_{\text{cause}} = (700)(4)\cos 15^\circ - 700(9.8)\sin 15^\circ \approx 2704.6 - 1775.5 \approx 929.1 \text{N}$ --- **9) What is the frictional force required to keep the car on the curve?** $F_{\text{fric}} = F_{\text{cause}} \approx \boxed{9.29\times 10^2 \text{N}}$ (directed **down the bank**, toward the center)

full_question: A car traveling at $20, \text{m/s}$ enters a curve of $100, \text{m}$ radius with a radial acceleration of $4, \text{m/s}^2$. If the mass of the car is $700, \text{kg}$, and the curve is banked $15^\circ$, what is the maximum velocity the car can achieve without sliding off the road $(\mu=0.6)$?
sub_question: Which diagram shows the proper forces and their components?
feedback_1: $A$: friction/acceleration directions are mislabeled for the slide up the bank case.
feedback_2: $B$: Correct weight is vertical, normal is perpendicular to the surface, and friction acts \emph{down} the bank at the high-speed limit.
feedback_3: $C$: swaps the roles/directions of friction and the acceleration component.
feedback_4: $D$: friction is drawn in the wrong direction relative to the impending motion.
solution: **1) Which diagram shows the proper forces and their components?** **B** --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N\cos\theta - F_f\sin\theta = mg, F_f=\mu N$ --- **3) What is the value of the normal force?** $N=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta-\mu\sin\theta} =\dfrac{700\cdot 9.8}{\cos15^\circ-0.6\sin15^\circ}\approx 8.46\times10^3 \text{N}$ --- **4) What is the value of the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N=0.6(8.46\times10^3)\approx 5.08\times10^3 \text{N}$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration that can be achieved by the car?** $m a_r = N\sin\theta + F_f\cos\theta;\Rightarrow; a_r = g, \dfrac{\sin\theta+\mu\cos\theta}{\cos\theta-\mu\sin\theta}$ --- **6) What is the value of $a_r$?** $a_r = 9.8, \dfrac{\sin15^\circ+0.6\cos15^\circ}{\cos15^\circ-0.6\sin15^\circ}\approx 10.14 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **7) Which equation would you use to calculate the angular velocity given $a_r$?** $a_r=\omega^2 r \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}$ --- **8) What is the value of the angular velocity?** $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{10.14}{100}}\approx 0.318 \text{rad/s}$ --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the linear velocity of the car given the angular velocity?** $v=\omega r$ (equivalently, $v=\sqrt{a_r r}$) --- **10) What is the maximum velocity the car can achieve without sliding off the road?** $v_{\max}=\omega r=0.318(100)\approx \boxed{31.8 \text{m/s}}$ *(Check: the given $20 \text{m/s}$ corresponds to $a_r=v^2/r=4 \text{m/s}^2$, which is well below this friction-limited maximum.)*

solution: **1) Which diagram shows the proper forces and their components?** **B** --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N\cos\theta - F_f\sin\theta = mg, F_f=\mu N$ --- **3) What is the value of the normal force?** $N=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta-\mu\sin\theta} =\dfrac{700\cdot 9.8}{\cos15^\circ-0.6\sin15^\circ}\approx 8.46\times10^3 \text{N}$ --- **4) What is the value of the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N=0.6(8.46\times10^3)\approx 5.08\times10^3 \text{N}$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration that can be achieved by the car?** $m a_r = N\sin\theta + F_f\cos\theta;\Rightarrow; a_r = g, \dfrac{\sin\theta+\mu\cos\theta}{\cos\theta-\mu\sin\theta}$ --- **6) What is the value of $a_r$?** $a_r = 9.8, \dfrac{\sin15^\circ+0.6\cos15^\circ}{\cos15^\circ-0.6\sin15^\circ}\approx 10.14 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **7) Which equation would you use to calculate the angular velocity given $a_r$?** $a_r=\omega^2 r \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}$ --- **8) What is the value of the angular velocity?** $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{10.14}{100}}\approx 0.318 \text{rad/s}$ --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the linear velocity of the car given the angular velocity?** $v=\omega r$ (equivalently, $v=\sqrt{a_r r}$) --- **10) What is the maximum velocity the car can achieve without sliding off the road?** $v_{\max}=\omega r=0.318(100)\approx \boxed{31.8 \text{m/s}}$ *(Check: the given $20 \text{m/s}$ corresponds to $a_r=v^2/r=4 \text{m/s}^2$, which is well below this friction-limited maximum.)*

full_question: A car traveling at $20, \text{m/s}$ enters a curve of $100, \text{m}$ radius with a radial acceleration of $4, \text{m/s}^2$. If the mass of the car is $700, \text{kg}$, and the curve is banked $15^\circ$, what is the maximum velocity the car can achieve without sliding off the road $(\mu=0.6)$?
sub_question: What is the maximum velocity the car can achieve without sliding off the road?
solution: **1) Which diagram shows the proper forces and their components?** **B** --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N\cos\theta - F_f\sin\theta = mg, F_f=\mu N$ --- **3) What is the value of the normal force?** $N=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta-\mu\sin\theta} =\dfrac{700\cdot 9.8}{\cos15^\circ-0.6\sin15^\circ}\approx 8.46\times10^3 \text{N}$ --- **4) What is the value of the force of friction?** $F_f=\mu N=0.6(8.46\times10^3)\approx 5.08\times10^3 \text{N}$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration that can be achieved by the car?** $m a_r = N\sin\theta + F_f\cos\theta;\Rightarrow; a_r = g, \dfrac{\sin\theta+\mu\cos\theta}{\cos\theta-\mu\sin\theta}$ --- **6) What is the value of $a_r$?** $a_r = 9.8, \dfrac{\sin15^\circ+0.6\cos15^\circ}{\cos15^\circ-0.6\sin15^\circ}\approx 10.14 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **7) Which equation would you use to calculate the angular velocity given $a_r$?** $a_r=\omega^2 r \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}$ --- **8) What is the value of the angular velocity?** $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{10.14}{100}}\approx 0.318 \text{rad/s}$ --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the linear velocity of the car given the angular velocity?** $v=\omega r$ (equivalently, $v=\sqrt{a_r r}$) --- **10) What is the maximum velocity the car can achieve without sliding off the road?** $v_{\max}=\omega r=0.318(100)\approx \boxed{31.8 \text{m/s}}$ *(Check: the given $20 \text{m/s}$ corresponds to $a_r=v^2/r=4 \text{m/s}^2$, which is well below this friction-limited maximum.)*

full_question: In the individual pursuit event of track cycling, the competitors often travel at very slow speeds on a steeply banked curve while jockeying for position. What is the minimum velocity on a $37^\circ$ bank of radius $50, \text{m}$ if $\mu=0.7$?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the normal force?
feedback_1: Incorrect sign this subtracts the $a_r$ component that adds to $N$ on a bank.
feedback_2: Wrong components: mixes $\sin$ and $\cos$.
feedback_3: Correct: resolving perpendicular to the surface gives $N=mg\cos\theta + m a_r\sin\theta$.
feedback_4: Wrong components/sign for the banked surface.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** $N\cos\theta + F_f\sin\theta = mg, \text{with }F_f=\mu N \text{(friction acts up the slope at the slow-speed limit)}$ --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration that can be achieved by the cyclist against this force?** $m a_r = N\sin\theta - F_f\cos\theta$ --- **3) What is the value of $a_r$?** $a_r = g, \dfrac{\sin\theta-\mu\cos\theta}{\cos\theta+\mu\sin\theta} = 9.8, \dfrac{\sin 37^\circ-0.7\cos 37^\circ}{\cos 37^\circ+0.7\sin 37^\circ} \approx 0.344 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **4) Which equation would you use to calculate the angular velocity given $a_r$?** $a_r=\omega^2 r \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}$ --- **5) What is the value of the angular velocity?** $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{0.344}{50}}\approx 0.0829 \text{rad/s}$ --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the linear velocity of the cyclist given the angular velocity?** $v=\omega r\quad(\text{equivalently }v=\sqrt{a_r r})$ --- **7) What is the minimum velocity on a $37^\circ$ bank of radius $50, \text{m}$ if $\mu=0.7$?** $v_{\min}=\sqrt{a_r r}=\sqrt{0.344\times 50}\approx \boxed{4.15 \text{m/s}}$

full_question: In the individual pursuit event of track cycling, the competitors often travel at very slow speeds on a steeply banked curve while jockeying for position. What is the maximum bank angle for the track ( = 0.7) if the cyclist can maintain a velocity of 1.5 m/s on a bank of radius 50 m?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?
feedback_1: Incorrect $w^2r$ gives $a_r$, not $w$; wrong dimensions.
feedback_2: Correct $v_t=!wr\Rightarrow w=\dfrac{v_t}{r}$.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** $\displaystyle \omega=\frac{v}{r}$ --- **2) What is the value of the angular velocity?** $\displaystyle \omega=\frac{1.5}{50}=0.03 \text{rad/s}$ --- **3) Which equation would you use to calculate the radial acceleration given $\omega $?** $\displaystyle a_r=\omega^2 r$ --- **4) What is the value of the radial acceleration?** $\displaystyle a_r=(0.03)^2(50)=0.045 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the force of friction required to keep the cyclist from sliding down the incline?** At the slow-speed limit friction acts **up** the slope and is at its maximum: $\displaystyle F_f=\mu N$. --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** Vertical balance: $\displaystyle N\cos q+F_f\sin q=mg$. --- **7) What is the value of the force of friction required to keep the cyclist from sliding down the incline?** Using $F_f=\mu N$ in the vertical balance: $\displaystyle F_f=\mu N=\mu, \frac{mg}{\cos q+\mu\sin q}\quad(\text{acts up the slope}).$ --- **8) How would you solve for the maximum angle of the bank?** Use the radial (inward) balance with $F_f=\mu N$: $\displaystyle m a_r=N\sin q-F_f\cos q$, eliminate $N$ with the vertical equation. --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the maximum angle of the bank?** $\displaystyle \frac{v^2}{rg}= \frac{\sin q-\mu\cos q}{\cos q+\mu\sin q}$ --- **10) After subbing in all known values what are we left with?** $\displaystyle \frac{1.5^2}{50\cdot 9.8}= \frac{\sin q-0.7\cos q}{\cos q+0.7\sin q}$ --- **11) Which trigonometric function would you use to solve for $q$?** Use $\displaystyle \tan q=\frac{\sin q}{\cos q}$. --- **12) After subbing in to this equation (i.e., $\tan q=\sin q/\cos q$) what are we left with?** Let $t=\tan q$: $\displaystyle 0.00459184=\frac{t-0.7}{1+0.7t} \Rightarrow t\approx 0.7069 \Rightarrow q=\arctan(0.7069)$. --- **13) What is the maximum bank angle for the track?** $\displaystyle q_{\max}\approx \boxed{35.3^\circ}$

for the track?** $\displaystyle q_{\max}\approx \boxed{35.3^\circ}$

full_question: In the individual pursuit event of track cycling, the competitors often travel at very slow speeds on a steeply banked curve while jockeying for position. What is the maximum bank angle for the track ( = 0.7) if the cyclist can maintain a velocity of 1.5 m/s on a bank of radius 50 m?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the force of friction required to keep the cyclist from sliding down the incline?
feedback_1: Incorrect this is the downslope component of weight.
feedback_2: Correct friction magnitude is $\mu N$.
feedback_4: Too generic; not the friction law.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** $\displaystyle \omega=\frac{v}{r}$ --- **2) What is the value of the angular velocity?** $\displaystyle \omega=\frac{1.5}{50}=0.03 \text{rad/s}$ --- **3) Which equation would you use to calculate the radial acceleration given $\omega $?** $\displaystyle a_r=\omega^2 r$ --- **4) What is the value of the radial acceleration?** $\displaystyle a_r=(0.03)^2(50)=0.045 \text{m/s}^2$ --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the force of friction required to keep the cyclist from sliding down the incline?** At the slow-speed limit friction acts **up** the slope and is at its maximum: $\displaystyle F_f=\mu N$. --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the normal force?** Vertical balance: $\displaystyle N\cos q+F_f\sin q=mg$. --- **7) What is the value of the force of friction required to keep the cyclist from sliding down the incline?** Using $F_f=\mu N$ in the vertical balance: $\displaystyle F_f=\mu N=\mu, \frac{mg}{\cos q+\mu\sin q}\quad(\text{acts up the slope}).$ --- **8) How would you solve for the maximum angle of the bank?** Use the radial (inward) balance with $F_f=\mu N$: $\displaystyle m a_r=N\sin q-F_f\cos q$, eliminate $N$ with the vertical equation. --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the maximum angle of the bank?** $\displaystyle \frac{v^2}{rg}= \frac{\sin q-\mu\cos q}{\cos q+\mu\sin q}$ --- **10) After subbing in all known values what are we left with?** $\displaystyle \frac{1.5^2}{50\cdot 9.8}= \frac{\sin q-0.7\cos q}{\cos q+0.7\sin q}$ --- **11) Which trigonometric function would you use to solve for $q$?** Use $\displaystyle \tan q=\frac{\sin q}{\cos q}$. --- **12) After subbing in to this equation (i.e., $\tan q=\sin q/\cos q$) what are we left with?** Let $t=\tan q$: $\displaystyle 0.00459184=\frac{t-0.7}{1+0.7t} \Rightarrow t\approx 0.7069 \Rightarrow q=\arctan(0.7069)$. --- **13) What is the maximum bank angle for the track?** $\displaystyle q_{\max}\approx \boxed{35.3^\circ}$

full_question: A catapult always releases the stone at an angle of $60^\circ$ to the horizontal with a velocity of $20 m/s$. To get the maximum range, what is the minimum distance from the $12 m$ wall that it should be placed and still have the stone clear the wall?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after the situation is defined.
feedback_2: Correct a sketch fixes axes, knowns/unknowns, constraints.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve the launch velocity into horizontal and vertical components, then write the kinematic equations for each direction (choose (+\hat y) upward, (+\hat x) to the right). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics applied separately in (x) and (y) (Newton s laws with (a_x=0), (a_y=-g)). --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the vertical and horizontal components of velocity?** With (v_0=20~\mathrm{m/s}) and (\theta=60^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos60^\circ=20\cdot \tfrac12=10~\mathrm{m/s},\qquad v_{0y}=v_0\sin60^\circ=20\cdot \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}=10\sqrt3\approx17.32~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the time the stone is at (12~\mathrm{m}) (the wall height)?** Use the vertical position: (;y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **7) At what time(s) is the stone at (12~\mathrm{m})?** Solve (12=17.32,t-4.9,t^2\Rightarrow 4.9t^2-17.32t+12=0): [ t=\frac{17.32\pm\sqrt{17.32^2-4(4.9)(12)}}{2(4.9)}={,0.946~\mathrm{s},;2.589~\mathrm{s},}. ] (The first is on the way up; the second on the way down.) --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal distance of the catapult from the wall?** Use (x=v_{0x}t) with the **earliest** time (to just clear the wall). --- **9) What is the minimum distance from the (12~\mathrm{m}) wall that the catapult can be placed and still clear it?** [ x_{\min}=v_{0x}t_{\text{up}}=(10~\mathrm{m/s})(0.946~\mathrm{s})\approx 9.46~\mathrm{m}. ] So, the catapult should be placed **about (9.5~\mathrm{m})** from the wall (closer would hit it on ascent).$

full_question: A catapult always releases the stone at an angle of $60^\circ$ to the horizontal with a velocity of $20 m/s$. To get the maximum range, what is the minimum distance from the $12 m$ wall that it should be placed and still have the stone clear the wall?
sub_question: How are the equations of motion derived?
feedback_1: No displacement comes after integrating velocity.
feedback_2: Correct integrate $a!\to!v$ then $v!\to!x, y$.
feedback_4: A tool isn t the derivation.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve the launch velocity into horizontal and vertical components, then write the kinematic equations for each direction (choose (+\hat y) upward, (+\hat x) to the right). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics applied separately in (x) and (y) (Newton s laws with (a_x=0), (a_y=-g)). --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the vertical and horizontal components of velocity?** With (v_0=20~\mathrm{m/s}) and (\theta=60^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos60^\circ=20\cdot \tfrac12=10~\mathrm{m/s},\qquad v_{0y}=v_0\sin60^\circ=20\cdot \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}=10\sqrt3\approx17.32~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the time the stone is at (12~\mathrm{m}) (the wall height)?** Use the vertical position: (;y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **7) At what time(s) is the stone at (12~\mathrm{m})?** Solve (12=17.32,t-4.9,t^2\Rightarrow 4.9t^2-17.32t+12=0): [ t=\frac{17.32\pm\sqrt{17.32^2-4(4.9)(12)}}{2(4.9)}={,0.946~\mathrm{s},;2.589~\mathrm{s},}. ] (The first is on the way up; the second on the way down.) --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal distance of the catapult from the wall?** Use (x=v_{0x}t) with the **earliest** time (to just clear the wall). --- **9) What is the minimum distance from the (12~\mathrm{m}) wall that the catapult can be placed and still clear it?** [ x_{\min}=v_{0x}t_{\text{up}}=(10~\mathrm{m/s})(0.946~\mathrm{s})\approx 9.46~\mathrm{m}. ] So, the catapult should be placed **about (9.5~\mathrm{m})** from the wall (closer would hit it on ascent).$

full_question: A tennis ball is hit horizontally with an initial velocity of $35 m/s$, at a distance of $1.8 m$ above the ground. How long will it take for the ball to hit the ground?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after setup.
feedback_2: Correct the diagram fixes axes and givens.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (choose (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) applied separately in (x) and (y) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at any time?** Use the vertical position: (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **6) What is the initial vertical velocity?** Since the ball is hit horizontally, (;v_{0y}=0.) --- **7) How long will it take for the ball to hit the ground?** Set (y(t)=0) with (y_0=1.8~\mathrm{m}) and (v_{0y}=0): [ 0=1.8-\tfrac12(9.8)t^2 ;\Rightarrow; t=\sqrt{\frac{2(1.8)}{9.8}} =\sqrt{\frac{1.8}{4.9}}\approx 0.606~\mathrm{s}. ] So it takes **about (0.61~\mathrm{s})** to hit the ground.$

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at any time?** Use the vertical position: (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **6) What is the initial vertical velocity?** Since the ball is hit horizontally, (;v_{0y}=0.) --- **7) How long will it take for the ball to hit the ground?** Set (y(t)=0) with (y_0=1.8~\mathrm{m}) and (v_{0y}=0): [ 0=1.8-\tfrac12(9.8)t^2 ;\Rightarrow; t=\sqrt{\frac{2(1.8)}{9.8}} =\sqrt{\frac{1.8}{4.9}}\approx 0.606~\mathrm{s}. ] So it takes **about (0.61~\mathrm{s})** to hit the ground.$

full_question: What is the minimum velocity that the ball can have with a horizontal trajectory ($\alpha=0$) that will still clear the net? Diagram: $y_0=2.0 m$, net height $1.1 m$ at $x=12.2 m$.
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after setup.
feedback_2: Correct.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the initial vertical velocity?** For a horizontal hit, (;v_{0y}=0.) --- **6) Which equation can you use to find the time the ball is (1.1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Use vertical position: (;y(t)=y_0-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **7) What is the next step?** Set (y(t)=1.1~\mathrm{m}) with (y_0=2.0~\mathrm{m}) and solve for (t). --- **8) At what time is the ball (1.1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** [ 1.1=2.0-\tfrac12(9.8)t^2 ;\Rightarrow; \tfrac12(9.8)t^2=0.9 ;\Rightarrow; t=\sqrt{\frac{2(0.9)}{9.8}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.8}{9.8}}\approx 0.429~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **9) Which equation can you use to find the horizontal velocity?** Use (x=v_{0x}t\Rightarrow v_{0x}=\dfrac{x}{t}.) --- **10) What is the minimum velocity (horizontal) that still clears the net?** [ v_{\min}= \frac{x}{t}=\frac{12.2~\mathrm{m}}{0.429~\mathrm{s}} \approx 28.5~\mathrm{m/s}. ] So the ball must have a horizontal speed of **about (28.5~\mathrm{m/s})** to just clear the net at (x=12.2~\mathrm{m}).$

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the initial vertical velocity?** For a horizontal hit, (;v_{0y}=0.) --- **6) Which equation can you use to find the time the ball is (1.1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Use vertical position: (;y(t)=y_0-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **7) What is the next step?** Set (y(t)=1.1~\mathrm{m}) with (y_0=2.0~\mathrm{m}) and solve for (t). --- **8) At what time is the ball (1.1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** [ 1.1=2.0-\tfrac12(9.8)t^2 ;\Rightarrow; \tfrac12(9.8)t^2=0.9 ;\Rightarrow; t=\sqrt{\frac{2(0.9)}{9.8}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.8}{9.8}}\approx 0.429~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **9) Which equation can you use to find the horizontal velocity?** Use (x=v_{0x}t\Rightarrow v_{0x}=\dfrac{x}{t}.) --- **10) What is the minimum velocity (horizontal) that still clears the net?** [ v_{\min}= \frac{x}{t}=\frac{12.2~\mathrm{m}}{0.429~\mathrm{s}} \approx 28.5~\mathrm{m/s}. ] So the ball must have a horizontal speed of **about (28.5~\mathrm{m/s})** to just clear the net at (x=12.2~\mathrm{m}).$

full_question: What is the maximum downward trajectory ($\alpha$) that the ball can have with an initial velocity $v_0=40 m/s$ and still clear the net? (Launch height $y_0=2.0 m$; net height $1.1 m$ at $x=12.2 m$.)
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after setup.
feedback_2: Correct the diagram fixes axes and givens.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve the motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the time the ball is (1.1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Use vertical position at the net: (;1.1=y_0+v_0\sin\alpha,t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **6) What is the next step?** Insert (y_0=2.0~\mathrm{m}) and keep (t) and (\alpha) as unknowns: (;1.1=2.0+v_0\sin\alpha,t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find how long it takes for the ball to travel (12.2~\mathrm{m})?** Horizontal motion: (;x=v_0\cos\alpha,t \Rightarrow t=\dfrac{x}{v_0\cos\alpha}) with (x=12.2~\mathrm{m}.) --- **8) What is the next step?** Substitute (t=\dfrac{x}{v_0\cos\alpha}) into the vertical equation. --- **9) Can we manipulate these two equations to solve for both unknowns (hint (\cos^{-2}\alpha=1+\tan^2\alpha))?** Yes. Substituting and simplifying gives [ 1.1=2.0+x\tan\alpha-\frac{g x^2}{2v_0^{,2}}\sec^2\alpha ] [ -0.9=x\tan\alpha-\frac{g x^2}{2v_0^{,2}}\left(1+\tan^2\alpha\right). ] Let (T=\tan\alpha) and (A=\dfrac{g x^2}{2v_0^{,2}}). Then [ A T^2- x T-(0.9-A)=0. ] --- **10) What is the maximum downward trajectory ((\alpha)) that the ball can have with (v_0=40~\mathrm{m/s}) and still clear the net?** With (x=12.2~\mathrm{m}), (g=9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}), (v_0=40~\mathrm{m/s}): (A=\dfrac{9.8(12.2)^2}{2(40)^2}\approx 0.456.) Solve (0.456,T^2-12.2,T-0.444=0) to get (;T=\tan\alpha\in{26.80, -0.03636}.) The downward case is (T<0): [ \alpha=\arctan(-0.03636)\approx -2.08^\circ. ] So the ball can be hit at up to **about (2.1^\circ) downward** and still clear the net.$

sub_question: Can we manipulate these two equations to solve for both unknowns (hint $\cos^{-2}\alpha=1+\tan^2\alpha$)?
feedback_1: Correct set $t=\dfrac{x}{v_{ox}}$ in $y(t)$ and solve the quadratic in $\tan\alpha$.
feedback_2: We can see hint.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve the motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the time the ball is (1.1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Use vertical position at the net: (;1.1=y_0+v_0\sin\alpha,t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **6) What is the next step?** Insert (y_0=2.0~\mathrm{m}) and keep (t) and (\alpha) as unknowns: (;1.1=2.0+v_0\sin\alpha,t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find how long it takes for the ball to travel (12.2~\mathrm{m})?** Horizontal motion: (;x=v_0\cos\alpha,t \Rightarrow t=\dfrac{x}{v_0\cos\alpha}) with (x=12.2~\mathrm{m}.) --- **8) What is the next step?** Substitute (t=\dfrac{x}{v_0\cos\alpha}) into the vertical equation. --- **9) Can we manipulate these two equations to solve for both unknowns (hint (\cos^{-2}\alpha=1+\tan^2\alpha))?** Yes. Substituting and simplifying gives [ 1.1=2.0+x\tan\alpha-\frac{g x^2}{2v_0^{,2}}\sec^2\alpha ] [ -0.9=x\tan\alpha-\frac{g x^2}{2v_0^{,2}}\left(1+\tan^2\alpha\right). ] Let (T=\tan\alpha) and (A=\dfrac{g x^2}{2v_0^{,2}}). Then [ A T^2- x T-(0.9-A)=0. ] --- **10) What is the maximum downward trajectory ((\alpha)) that the ball can have with (v_0=40~\mathrm{m/s}) and still clear the net?** With (x=12.2~\mathrm{m}), (g=9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}), (v_0=40~\mathrm{m/s}): (A=\dfrac{9.8(12.2)^2}{2(40)^2}\approx 0.456.) Solve (0.456,T^2-12.2,T-0.444=0) to get (;T=\tan\alpha\in{26.80, -0.03636}.) The downward case is (T<0): [ \alpha=\arctan(-0.03636)\approx -2.08^\circ. ] So the ball can be hit at up to **about (2.1^\circ) downward** and still clear the net.$

full_question: A projectile reaches a maximum height in 0.356 seconds. Find the initial vertical velocity.
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after setup.
feedback_2: Correct the diagram fixes axes and givens.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve the motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to solve for the vertical component of velocity at any given time?** Use (;v_y(t)=v_{0y}-gt.) --- **6) What is the vertical component of velocity when the projectile reaches its apex?** At the top, (;v_y=0.) --- **7) Find the initial vertical velocity.** Set (v_y=0) at (t=0.356~\mathrm{s}): [ 0=v_{0y}-g,t ;\Rightarrow; v_{0y}=gt=(9.8)(0.356)=3.4888~\mathrm{m/s}\approx 3.49~\mathrm{m/s} (\text{upward}). ]$

full_question: A quarterback throws a football at an unknown angle with respect to the horizontal. If the height of release and catch is $2.3 m$ above the ground, the total time of flight is $3.5 s$, and the horizontal distance from ball (at release) to high point (HP) is $27.0 m$, at what angle did the quarterback release the ball?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after setup.
feedback_2: Correct - the diagram fixes axes and givens.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity of the ball at its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which equation do you use to find the initial vertical velocity of the ball?** Use (;v_y=v_{0y}-gt) and set (v_y=0) at the apex time (t_\text{up}). --- **7) What is the initial vertical velocity of the ball?** Given total flight time (T=3.5~\mathrm{s}) and equal release/catch heights, (t_\text{up}=T/2=1.75~\mathrm{s}). [ v_{0y}=g,t_\text{up}=(9.8)(1.75)=17.15~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the initial horizontal component of velocity?** Use (x=v_{0x}t) from release to the high point: (v_{0x}=\dfrac{x_\text{to HP}}{t_\text{up}}.) --- **9) What is the initial horizontal component of velocity?** [ v_{0x}=\frac{27.0}{1.75}=15.43~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **10) How do we use the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity to find the angle of release?** (;\tan\theta=\dfrac{v_{0y}}{v_{0x}}.) --- **11) At what angle did the quarterback release the ball?** [ \theta=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{17.15}{15.43}\right)\approx \tan^{-1}(1.111)\approx 48.2^\circ. ] So the ball was released at **about (48^\circ)** above the horizontal.$

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity of the ball at its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which equation do you use to find the initial vertical velocity of the ball?** Use (;v_y=v_{0y}-gt) and set (v_y=0) at the apex time (t_\text{up}). --- **7) What is the initial vertical velocity of the ball?** Given total flight time (T=3.5~\mathrm{s}) and equal release/catch heights, (t_\text{up}=T/2=1.75~\mathrm{s}). [ v_{0y}=g,t_\text{up}=(9.8)(1.75)=17.15~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the initial horizontal component of velocity?** Use (x=v_{0x}t) from release to the high point: (v_{0x}=\dfrac{x_\text{to HP}}{t_\text{up}}.) --- **9) What is the initial horizontal component of velocity?** [ v_{0x}=\frac{27.0}{1.75}=15.43~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **10) How do we use the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity to find the angle of release?** (;\tan\theta=\dfrac{v_{0y}}{v_{0x}}.) --- **11) At what angle did the quarterback release the ball?** [ \theta=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{17.15}{15.43}\right)\approx \tan^{-1}(1.111)\approx 48.2^\circ. ] So the ball was released at **about (48^\circ)** above the horizontal.$

full_question: Find the maximum height achieved in the jump. (take-off velocity = $8~\mathrm{m/s}$, $45^\circ$ above horizontal)
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after setup.
feedback_2: Correct the diagram fixes axes and givens.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the initial vertical velocity?** With (v_0=8~\mathrm{m/s}) and (\theta=45^\circ): [ v_{0y}=v_0\sin45^\circ=8\cdot \frac{\sqrt2}{2}=4\sqrt2\approx 5.66~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) What is the vertical component of velocity at its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the time when the jumper is at his maximum height?** Use (;v_y=v_{0y}-gt) and set (v_y=0). --- **8) How long does it take for the jumper to reach his maximum height?** [ 0=v_{0y}-gt ;\Rightarrow; t_\text{up}=\frac{v_{0y}}{g}=\frac{5.66}{9.8}\approx 0.578~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the maximum height at any given time?** Use either (;y_\text{max}-y_0=\dfrac{v_{0y}^2}{2g}) or evaluate (y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2) at (t=t_\text{up}). --- **10) What is the maximum height the jumper achieves?** [ \Delta y_\text{max}=\frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g}=\frac{(5.66)^2}{2(9.8)} =\frac{32.0}{19.6}\approx 1.63~\mathrm{m}. ] So the jumper rises **about (1.63~\mathrm{m})** above take-off.$

full_question: Calculate the total distance travelled by a ball that is thrown vertically upward from a $10 m$ tower with an initial velocity of $4 m/s$ by the time it hits the ground.
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Do this after setup.
feedback_2: Correct the diagram fixes axes and givens.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve the motion into vertical (here the only relevant direction) and write the constant-acceleration kinematics (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Vertical (relevant here): (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) Horizontal (not used here): (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity of the ball at its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the time it takes for the ball to reach its apex?** Use (;v_y=v_{0y}-gt) and set (v_y=0). --- **7) How long does it take for the ball to reach its apex?** [ 0=v_{0}-gt ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}=\frac{v_{0}}{g} =\frac{4}{9.8}\approx 0.408~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at its apex?** Use (;y_{\max}-y_0=\dfrac{v_{0}^{2}}{2g}) (or (y(t)=y_0+v_0 t-\tfrac12gt^2) at (t=t_{\text{up}})). --- **9) What is the height of the ball at the apex?** [ \Delta y_{\text{up}}=\frac{v_0^2}{2g}=\frac{4^2}{2(9.8)}=\frac{16}{19.6}\approx 0.816~\mathrm{m}, ] [ y_{\max}=y_0+\Delta y_{\text{up}}=10+0.816\approx 10.816~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **10) What is the total distance travelled by the ball?** Upward distance (=0.816~\mathrm{m}). Downward distance (=y_{\max}-0=10.816~\mathrm{m}). [ s_{\text{total}}=0.816+10.816\approx 11.632~\mathrm{m}. ] So the ball travels **about (11.63~\mathrm{m})** in total before hitting the ground.$

Horizontal (not used here): (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity of the ball at its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the time it takes for the ball to reach its apex?** Use (;v_y=v_{0y}-gt) and set (v_y=0). --- **7) How long does it take for the ball to reach its apex?** [ 0=v_{0}-gt ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}=\frac{v_{0}}{g} =\frac{4}{9.8}\approx 0.408~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at its apex?** Use (;y_{\max}-y_0=\dfrac{v_{0}^{2}}{2g}) (or (y(t)=y_0+v_0 t-\tfrac12gt^2) at (t=t_{\text{up}})). --- **9) What is the height of the ball at the apex?** [ \Delta y_{\text{up}}=\frac{v_0^2}{2g}=\frac{4^2}{2(9.8)}=\frac{16}{19.6}\approx 0.816~\mathrm{m}, ] [ y_{\max}=y_0+\Delta y_{\text{up}}=10+0.816\approx 10.816~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **10) What is the total distance travelled by the ball?** Upward distance (=0.816~\mathrm{m}). Downward distance (=y_{\max}-0=10.816~\mathrm{m}). [ s_{\text{total}}=0.816+10.816\approx 11.632~\mathrm{m}. ] So the ball travels **about (11.63~\mathrm{m})** in total before hitting the ground.$

full_question: A kicker in football always kicks the ball from the ground with a velocity of 20 m/s and a trajectory of 45 . What is the maximum distance from the goalposts that the kicker can be successful if the height of the crossbar is 3 m?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the vertical and horizontal components of initial velocity?** With (v_0=20~\mathrm{m/s}) and (\theta=45^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos45^\circ=\frac{20}{\sqrt2}\approx 14.14~\mathrm{m/s}, v_{0y}=v_0\sin45^\circ=\frac{20}{\sqrt2}\approx 14.14~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) Which equation can you use to find the height of the ball at a particular time?** (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) Here (y_0=0) (kicked from ground). --- **7) What is the next step?** Set (y(t)=3~\mathrm{m}) and solve the quadratic for (t). --- **8) At what time(s) is the ball (3~\mathrm{m}) high (the height it needs to clear the goal posts)?** Solve (3=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2\Rightarrow 4.9t^2-14.14t+3=0): [ t=\frac{14.14\pm\sqrt{14.14^2-4(4.9)(3)}}{2(4.9)}={,0.231~\mathrm{s},;2.656~\mathrm{s},}. ] (The second time is on the way down and gives the farthest distance.) --- **9) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal displacement at any specific time?** (;x(t)=v_{0x}t.) --- **10) What is the maximum distance from the goalposts that the kicker can be successful if the height of the crossbar is (3~\mathrm{m})?** Use the later time (t=2.656~\mathrm{s}): [ x_{\max}=v_{0x}t=(14.14)(2.656)\approx 37.6~\mathrm{m}. ] So the kicker can be successful from **about (38~\mathrm{m})** (to just clear a (3~\mathrm{m}) crossbar).$

full_question: A trampolinist requires 1.9 seconds of total flight time to perform a full twisting, double somersault. What is the minimum vertical velocity needed at take-off?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity of the trampolinist at his/her apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) At what time is the trampolinist at his/her apex?** With total flight time (T=1.9~\mathrm{s}) and equal take-off/landing heights, (t_\text{up}=T/2=0.95~\mathrm{s}.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the velocity at any given time?** (;v_y(t)=v_{0y}-gt.) --- **8) What is the next step?** Set (v_y=0) at (t=t_\text{up}) and solve for (v_{0y}). --- **9) What is the minimum vertical velocity needed at take-off?** [ v_{0y}=g,t_\text{up}=(9.8)(0.95)=9.31~\mathrm{m/s} (\text{upward}). ] So the trampolinist needs **about (9.3~\mathrm{m/s})** of upward take-off speed.$

solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at any particular time?** (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) Here (y_0=0), (v_{0y}=v_0\sin45^\circ=\dfrac{25}{\sqrt2}). --- **6) At what time(s) is the ball (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground (the height the player needs to catch it)?** Solve (1=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2): [ 4.9t^2-\left(\tfrac{25}{\sqrt2}\right)t+1=0 ;\Rightarrow; t={,0.0575~\mathrm{s},;3.550~\mathrm{s},}. ] (Use the **later** time on the way down.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal displacement at any given time?** (;x(t)=v_{0x}t,) with (v_{0x}=v_0\cos45^\circ=\dfrac{25}{\sqrt2}). --- **8) What is the horizontal displacement of the ball when the receiver needs to catch it?** At (t=3.550~\mathrm{s}): [ x_b=v_{0x}t=\left(\tfrac{25}{\sqrt2}\right)(3.550)\approx 62.76~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **9) How much time does the player have to run the remaining distance in order to catch the ball (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** He starts running at (t=1.00~\mathrm{s}), so [ \Delta t = 3.550-1.000 = 2.550~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **10) What is the remaining distance (horizontal displacement) that the player has to run to catch the ball (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Receiver s initial position is (x=40.0~\mathrm{m}): [ \Delta x = x_b-40.0 = 62.76-40.00 = 22.76~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **11) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal velocity?** Average speed needed: (;v=\dfrac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}.) --- **12) What was the average velocity that the receiver had to maintain to catch the ball at a height of (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** [ v=\frac{22.76~\mathrm{m}}{2.550~\mathrm{s}}\approx 8.92~\mathrm{m/s} ] directed **downfield** (toward increasing (x)).$

full_question: A football was kicked off the ground at a velocity of 25 m/s at 45 above the horizontal. A receiver 40 m away realized after 1 second of flight that the ball was going to travel over his head. What was the average velocity that the receiver had to maintain to catch the ball at a height of 1 m above the ground?
sub_question: How are the equations of motion derived?
feedback_1: Displacement comes after velocity.
feedback_2: Correct: integrate $a!\to!v!\to!y$.
feedback_4: Tools help, but the physics gives the equations.

sub_question: What is the remaining distance (horizontal displacement) that the player has to run to catch the ball 1 m above the ground?
feedback_1: That would be too little.
feedback_2: That s the ball s $x$, not the remaining distance.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at any particular time?** (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) Here (y_0=0), (v_{0y}=v_0\sin45^\circ=\dfrac{25}{\sqrt2}). --- **6) At what time(s) is the ball (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground (the height the player needs to catch it)?** Solve (1=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2): [ 4.9t^2-\left(\tfrac{25}{\sqrt2}\right)t+1=0 ;\Rightarrow; t={,0.0575~\mathrm{s},;3.550~\mathrm{s},}. ] (Use the **later** time on the way down.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal displacement at any given time?** (;x(t)=v_{0x}t,) with (v_{0x}=v_0\cos45^\circ=\dfrac{25}{\sqrt2}). --- **8) What is the horizontal displacement of the ball when the receiver needs to catch it?** At (t=3.550~\mathrm{s}): [ x_b=v_{0x}t=\left(\tfrac{25}{\sqrt2}\right)(3.550)\approx 62.76~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **9) How much time does the player have to run the remaining distance in order to catch the ball (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** He starts running at (t=1.00~\mathrm{s}), so [ \Delta t = 3.550-1.000 = 2.550~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **10) What is the remaining distance (horizontal displacement) that the player has to run to catch the ball (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Receiver s initial position is (x=40.0~\mathrm{m}): [ \Delta x = x_b-40.0 = 62.76-40.00 = 22.76~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **11) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal velocity?** Average speed needed: (;v=\dfrac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}.) --- **12) What was the average velocity that the receiver had to maintain to catch the ball at a height of (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** [ v=\frac{22.76~\mathrm{m}}{2.550~\mathrm{s}}\approx 8.92~\mathrm{m/s} ] directed **downfield** (toward increasing (x)).$

full_question: A volleyball player spikes the ball from a height of 2.8 m with trajectory q degrees below horizontal. Find q if the ball lands 3 m away at a time of 0.5 seconds?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward, (+\hat x) toward the landing spot). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal component of velocity?** (;x=v_{0x}t\Rightarrow v_{0x}=\dfrac{x}{t}.) --- **6) What is the horizontal component of velocity?** With (x=3.0~\mathrm{m}) and (t=0.50~\mathrm{s}): [ v_{0x}=\frac{3.0}{0.50}=6.0~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the vertical component of velocity (hint (y(t)=0))?** Use (y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2) and set (y(t)=0) at landing. --- **8) What is the vertical component of velocity?** [ 0=2.8+v_{0y}(0.50)-\tfrac12(9.8)(0.50)^2 ;\Rightarrow; 0=2.8+0.5v_{0y}-1.225 ] [ 0.5v_{0y}=-1.575;\Rightarrow; v_{0y}=-3.15~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **9) How would you find the initial angle at which the player struck the ball?** Use (;\tan q=\dfrac{|v_{0y}|}{v_{0x}}) for a downward launch (so (q>0) below horizontal). --- **10) What is the value of (q)?** [ q=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{3.15}{6.0}\right)\approx \tan^{-1}(0.525)\approx 27.7^\circ (\text{below horizontal}). ]$

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal component of velocity?** (;x=v_{0x}t\Rightarrow v_{0x}=\dfrac{x}{t}.) --- **6) What is the horizontal component of velocity?** With (x=3.0~\mathrm{m}) and (t=0.50~\mathrm{s}): [ v_{0x}=\frac{3.0}{0.50}=6.0~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the vertical component of velocity (hint (y(t)=0))?** Use (y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2) and set (y(t)=0) at landing. --- **8) What is the vertical component of velocity?** [ 0=2.8+v_{0y}(0.50)-\tfrac12(9.8)(0.50)^2 ;\Rightarrow; 0=2.8+0.5v_{0y}-1.225 ] [ 0.5v_{0y}=-1.575;\Rightarrow; v_{0y}=-3.15~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **9) How would you find the initial angle at which the player struck the ball?** Use (;\tan q=\dfrac{|v_{0y}|}{v_{0x}}) for a downward launch (so (q>0) below horizontal). --- **10) What is the value of (q)?** [ q=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{3.15}{6.0}\right)\approx \tan^{-1}(0.525)\approx 27.7^\circ (\text{below horizontal}). ]$

feedback_1: Correct ratio; $q$ is below horizontal so report a positive angle below the axis.

full_question: A person throws a ball with an initial velocity of 20 m/s from a point located 2.0 m above the floor. Knowing that the ceiling of the gymnasium is 7.0 m high, determine the highest point at which the ball can strike the wall 20 m away. For simplicity, assume that the acceleration due to gravity is $-10 m/s^2$.
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-10~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity of the ball at its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the initial vertical velocity of the ball?** Use (;v_y(t)=v_{0y}-gt) and set (v_y=0) at the apex time (t_{\text{up}}). --- **7) When we sub in all known values into (v_y(t)=-9.81t+v_{0y}), what unknowns are we left with?** The two unknowns are (v_{0y}) and the time to apex (t_{\text{up}}). (We will use (g=10~\mathrm{m/s^2}) for calculations as stated.) --- **8) Which other equation will leave us with the same two unknowns ((v_{0y}, t))?** The vertical position at the apex (just below the (7~\mathrm{m}) ceiling to maximize wall height): [ y_{\max}=y_0+v_{0y}t_{\text{up}}-\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2=7. ] --- **9) How do you manipulate these equations to solve for each unknown?** From (0=v_{0y}-g t_{\text{up}}\Rightarrow v_{0y}=g t_{\text{up}}). Substitute into the height equation: [ 7= y_0+ (g t_{\text{up}})t_{\text{up}}-\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2 = y_0+\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2. ] --- **10) Which unknown should we solve for first?** Solve for (t_{\text{up}}), then back-solve for (v_{0y}). --- **11) What is the initial vertical velocity?** With (y_0=2.0~\mathrm{m}) and (g=10): [ 7 = 2 + \tfrac12(10)t_{\text{up}}^2 ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}^2=1 ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}=1.0~\mathrm{s}, ] [ v_{0y}=g t_{\text{up}}=10(1.0)=10~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **12) Knowing the vertical component and the initial velocity how can we find the horizontal component of velocity?** Use (v_0^2=v_{0x}^2+v_{0y}^2\Rightarrow v_{0x}=\sqrt{v_0^2-v_{0y}^2} =\sqrt{20^2-10^2}=10\sqrt3\approx 17.32~\mathrm{m/s}.) --- **13) Which equation would you use to find the total flight time?** Horizontal motion to the wall: (;x=v_{0x}t\Rightarrow t=\dfrac{20}{v_{0x}}.) --- **14) What is the total flight time?** [ t_{\text{wall}}=\frac{20}{10\sqrt3}=\frac{2}{\sqrt3}\approx 1.155~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **15) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at the end of its flight time (1.16 s)?** Vertical position: (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **16) What is the highest point at which the ball can strike the wall (20~\mathrm{m}) away?** [ y_{\text{wall}}=2 + (10)(1.155) - 5(1.155)^2 \approx 2 + 11.55 - 6.67 \approx 6.88~\mathrm{m}. ] So the ball can strike the wall as high as **about (6.9~\mathrm{m})** without hitting the (7.0~\mathrm{m}) ceiling en route (achieved with a (30^\circ) launch above horizontal).$

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity of the ball at its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the initial vertical velocity of the ball?** Use (;v_y(t)=v_{0y}-gt) and set (v_y=0) at the apex time (t_{\text{up}}). --- **7) When we sub in all known values into (v_y(t)=-9.81t+v_{0y}), what unknowns are we left with?** The two unknowns are (v_{0y}) and the time to apex (t_{\text{up}}). (We will use (g=10~\mathrm{m/s^2}) for calculations as stated.) --- **8) Which other equation will leave us with the same two unknowns ((v_{0y}, t))?** The vertical position at the apex (just below the (7~\mathrm{m}) ceiling to maximize wall height): [ y_{\max}=y_0+v_{0y}t_{\text{up}}-\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2=7. ] --- **9) How do you manipulate these equations to solve for each unknown?** From (0=v_{0y}-g t_{\text{up}}\Rightarrow v_{0y}=g t_{\text{up}}). Substitute into the height equation: [ 7= y_0+ (g t_{\text{up}})t_{\text{up}}-\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2 = y_0+\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2. ] --- **10) Which unknown should we solve for first?** Solve for (t_{\text{up}}), then back-solve for (v_{0y}). --- **11) What is the initial vertical velocity?** With (y_0=2.0~\mathrm{m}) and (g=10): [ 7 = 2 + \tfrac12(10)t_{\text{up}}^2 ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}^2=1 ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}=1.0~\mathrm{s}, ] [ v_{0y}=g t_{\text{up}}=10(1.0)=10~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **12) Knowing the vertical component and the initial velocity how can we find the horizontal component of velocity?** Use (v_0^2=v_{0x}^2+v_{0y}^2\Rightarrow v_{0x}=\sqrt{v_0^2-v_{0y}^2} =\sqrt{20^2-10^2}=10\sqrt3\approx 17.32~\mathrm{m/s}.) --- **13) Which equation would you use to find the total flight time?** Horizontal motion to the wall: (;x=v_{0x}t\Rightarrow t=\dfrac{20}{v_{0x}}.) --- **14) What is the total flight time?** [ t_{\text{wall}}=\frac{20}{10\sqrt3}=\frac{2}{\sqrt3}\approx 1.155~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **15) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at the end of its flight time (1.16 s)?** Vertical position: (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **16) What is the highest point at which the ball can strike the wall (20~\mathrm{m}) away?** [ y_{\text{wall}}=2 + (10)(1.155) - 5(1.155)^2 \approx 2 + 11.55 - 6.67 \approx 6.88~\mathrm{m}. ] So the ball can strike the wall as high as **about (6.9~\mathrm{m})** without hitting the (7.0~\mathrm{m}) ceiling en route (achieved with a (30^\circ) launch above horizontal).$

full_question: A person throws a ball with an initial velocity of 20 m/s from a point located 2.0 m above the floor. Knowing that the ceiling of the gymnasium is 7.0 m high, determine the highest point at which the ball can strike the wall 20 m away. sub_question: When we sub in all known values into $v_y(t)=-9.81t+v_{oy}$, what unknowns are we left with?
feedback_1: Only $v_{oy}$ isn t enough we also need time.
feedback_2: Correct: two unknowns remain.
feedback_3: That s just one of them.
feedback_4: We set $v_y$ at the apex; it isn t unknown.

Substitute into the height equation: [ 7= y_0+ (g t_{\text{up}})t_{\text{up}}-\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2 = y_0+\tfrac12 g t_{\text{up}}^2. ] --- **10) Which unknown should we solve for first?** Solve for (t_{\text{up}}), then back-solve for (v_{0y}). --- **11) What is the initial vertical velocity?** With (y_0=2.0~\mathrm{m}) and (g=10): [ 7 = 2 + \tfrac12(10)t_{\text{up}}^2 ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}^2=1 ;\Rightarrow; t_{\text{up}}=1.0~\mathrm{s}, ] [ v_{0y}=g t_{\text{up}}=10(1.0)=10~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **12) Knowing the vertical component and the initial velocity how can we find the horizontal component of velocity?** Use (v_0^2=v_{0x}^2+v_{0y}^2\Rightarrow v_{0x}=\sqrt{v_0^2-v_{0y}^2} =\sqrt{20^2-10^2}=10\sqrt3\approx 17.32~\mathrm{m/s}.) --- **13) Which equation would you use to find the total flight time?** Horizontal motion to the wall: (;x=v_{0x}t\Rightarrow t=\dfrac{20}{v_{0x}}.) --- **14) What is the total flight time?** [ t_{\text{wall}}=\frac{20}{10\sqrt3}=\frac{2}{\sqrt3}\approx 1.155~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **15) Which equation would you use to find the height of the ball at the end of its flight time (1.16 s)?** Vertical position: (;y(t)=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **16) What is the highest point at which the ball can strike the wall (20~\mathrm{m}) away?** [ y_{\text{wall}}=2 + (10)(1.155) - 5(1.155)^2 \approx 2 + 11.55 - 6.67 \approx 6.88~\mathrm{m}. ] So the ball can strike the wall as high as **about (6.9~\mathrm{m})** without hitting the (7.0~\mathrm{m}) ceiling en route (achieved with a (30^\circ) launch above horizontal).$

full_question: How long does it take for the ball to reach the hoop if q is 60 and v is 6 m/s.
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the vertical and horizontal components of velocity?** With (v_0=6~\mathrm{m/s}) and (q=60^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos60^\circ=6\cdot\tfrac12=3.0~\mathrm{m/s},\qquad v_{0y}=v_0\sin60^\circ=6\cdot\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}=3\sqrt3\approx5.196~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the time the ball is at (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Use vertical position: (;y(t)=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2). Set (y=1~\mathrm{m}). --- **7) How long does it take for the ball to reach the hoop if (q=60^\circ) and (v=6~\mathrm{m/s})?** Solve (1=5.196,t-4.9,t^2\Rightarrow 4.9t^2-5.196t+1=0): [ t=\frac{5.196\pm\sqrt{5.196^2-4(4.9)(1)}}{2(4.9)} ={,0.253~\mathrm{s},;0.808~\mathrm{s},}. ] The ball reaches (1~\mathrm{m}) twice; the **time to the hoop** (on the way down) is (\boxed{t\approx0.808~\mathrm{s}}).$

feedback_2: Correct: resolve with 60 .
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the vertical and horizontal components of velocity?** With (v_0=6~\mathrm{m/s}) and (q=60^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos60^\circ=6\cdot\tfrac12=3.0~\mathrm{m/s},\qquad v_{0y}=v_0\sin60^\circ=6\cdot\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}=3\sqrt3\approx5.196~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the time the ball is at (1~\mathrm{m}) above the ground?** Use vertical position: (;y(t)=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2). Set (y=1~\mathrm{m}). --- **7) How long does it take for the ball to reach the hoop if (q=60^\circ) and (v=6~\mathrm{m/s})?** Solve (1=5.196,t-4.9,t^2\Rightarrow 4.9t^2-5.196t+1=0): [ t=\frac{5.196\pm\sqrt{5.196^2-4(4.9)(1)}}{2(4.9)} ={,0.253~\mathrm{s},;0.808~\mathrm{s},}. ] The ball reaches (1~\mathrm{m}) twice; the **time to the hoop** (on the way down) is (\boxed{t\approx0.808~\mathrm{s}}).$
