full_question: If q is 75 and the ball took 0.972 seconds to reach the hoop, find the distance x. (given: $v = 6 m/s$)
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat x) toward the hoop, (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the horizontal component of velocity?** With (v_0=6~\mathrm{m/s}) and (q=75^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos 75^\circ=6\cos 75^\circ\approx 6(0.2588)=1.553~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) Which equation would you use to find horizontal displacement?** (;x=v_{0x}t.) --- **7) If (q=75^\circ) and the ball took (0.972~\mathrm{s}) to reach the hoop, find the distance (x) (given (v=6~\mathrm{m/s})).** [ x=v_{0x}t=(1.553)(0.972)\approx 1.51~\mathrm{m}. ] So the hoop is **about (1.51~\mathrm{m})** away horizontally.$

full_question: If q is 45 , what is the minimum velocity (v) that the ball needs to reach the height of the hoop?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity when the ball reaches its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which two equations can we use to solve for the initial vertical velocity ((v_{0y}))?** Use (v_y=v_{0y}-gt) (set (v_y=0) at the apex) and (y_{\max}-y_0=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2). Eliminating (t) gives [ y_{\max}-y_0=\frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g}. ] --- **7) How do we manipulate these equations to find initial velocity?** Set the required rise to the hoop height: (y_{\max}-y_0=1~\mathrm{m}). Then [ \frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g}=1 ;\Rightarrow; v_{0y}=\sqrt{2g(1)}. ] --- **8) Knowing the vertical component of velocity, how do we solve for the minimum initial velocity at (45^\circ)?** Use (v_{0y}=v\sin45^\circ=\dfrac{v}{\sqrt2}\Rightarrow v=\sqrt2,v_{0y}.) --- **9) What is the minimum velocity?** [ v_{0y}=\sqrt{2(9.8)(1)}=\sqrt{19.6}\approx 4.43~\mathrm{m/s}, ] [ v_{\min}=\sqrt2,v_{0y}\approx 1.414(4.43)\approx 6.26~\mathrm{m/s}. ] So the ball needs a **minimum initial speed of (\boxed{\approx 6.3~\mathrm{m/s}})** at (45^\circ) to reach the hoop height.$

solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What is the vertical velocity when the ball reaches its apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **6) Which two equations can we use to solve for the initial vertical velocity ((v_{0y}))?** Use (v_y=v_{0y}-gt) (set (v_y=0) at the apex) and (y_{\max}-y_0=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2). Eliminating (t) gives [ y_{\max}-y_0=\frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g}. ] --- **7) How do we manipulate these equations to find initial velocity?** Set the required rise to the hoop height: (y_{\max}-y_0=1~\mathrm{m}). Then [ \frac{v_{0y}^2}{2g}=1 ;\Rightarrow; v_{0y}=\sqrt{2g(1)}. ] --- **8) Knowing the vertical component of velocity, how do we solve for the minimum initial velocity at (45^\circ)?** Use (v_{0y}=v\sin45^\circ=\dfrac{v}{\sqrt2}\Rightarrow v=\sqrt2,v_{0y}.) --- **9) What is the minimum velocity?** [ v_{0y}=\sqrt{2(9.8)(1)}=\sqrt{19.6}\approx 4.43~\mathrm{m/s}, ] [ v_{\min}=\sqrt2,v_{0y}\approx 1.414(4.43)\approx 6.26~\mathrm{m/s}. ] So the ball needs a **minimum initial speed of (\boxed{\approx 6.3~\mathrm{m/s}})** at (45^\circ) to reach the hoop height.$

full_question: A prehistoric hunter is lying at the edge of a 7.5 m cliff looking down at a Stegasaur. If the hunter throws a 2.0 kg rock a horizontal distance of 3.0 m, what is the angle of release of the rock such that the total time of flight from the hunter to the stegasaur is 1.3 s? The stegasaur's head is 1.5 m above the ground.
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve the launch velocity into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward, (+\hat x) toward the stegosaur). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\text{m/s}^2.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What do we need in order to find the angle of release?** The initial components (v_{0x}) and (v_{0y}); then (\tan\theta=\dfrac{v_{0y}}{v_{0x}}). --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal component of velocity?** (;x=v_{0x}t \Rightarrow v_{0x}=\dfrac{x}{t}.) --- **7) What is the horizontal component of velocity?** [ v_{0x}=\frac{3.0~\text{m}}{1.3~\text{s}} \approx 2.31~\text{m/s}. ] --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the vertical component of velocity?** Use vertical position with the net drop ( \Delta y = y - y_0 = -6.0~\text{m}) (from (7.5) m to (1.5) m): (;\Delta y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **9) What is the vertical component of velocity?** [ -6.0 = v_{0y}(1.3)-\tfrac12(9.8)(1.3)^2 ;\Rightarrow; v_{0y}=\frac{-6.0+4.9(1.69)}{1.3} =\frac{2.281}{1.3}\approx 1.75~\text{m/s}. ] --- **10) How do we use the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity to find the angle of release?** (;\tan\theta=\dfrac{v_{0y}}{v_{0x}}.) --- **11) What is the angle of release of the rock (degrees)?** [ \theta=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{1.75}{2.31}\right)\approx \tan^{-1}(0.761)\approx 37.2^\circ. ] So the hunter must release the rock at **about (37^\circ) above the horizontal** to have a (1.3) s flight and land (3.0) m away at the stegosaur s head height.$

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What do we need in order to find the angle of release?** The initial components (v_{0x}) and (v_{0y}); then (\tan\theta=\dfrac{v_{0y}}{v_{0x}}). --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the horizontal component of velocity?** (;x=v_{0x}t \Rightarrow v_{0x}=\dfrac{x}{t}.) --- **7) What is the horizontal component of velocity?** [ v_{0x}=\frac{3.0~\text{m}}{1.3~\text{s}} \approx 2.31~\text{m/s}. ] --- **8) Which equation would you use to find the vertical component of velocity?** Use vertical position with the net drop ( \Delta y = y - y_0 = -6.0~\text{m}) (from (7.5) m to (1.5) m): (;\Delta y=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2.) --- **9) What is the vertical component of velocity?** [ -6.0 = v_{0y}(1.3)-\tfrac12(9.8)(1.3)^2 ;\Rightarrow; v_{0y}=\frac{-6.0+4.9(1.69)}{1.3} =\frac{2.281}{1.3}\approx 1.75~\text{m/s}. ] --- **10) How do we use the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity to find the angle of release?** (;\tan\theta=\dfrac{v_{0y}}{v_{0x}}.) --- **11) What is the angle of release of the rock (degrees)?** [ \theta=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{1.75}{2.31}\right)\approx \tan^{-1}(0.761)\approx 37.2^\circ. ] So the hunter must release the rock at **about (37^\circ) above the horizontal** to have a (1.3) s flight and land (3.0) m away at the stegosaur s head height.$

full_question: A golfer is teeing off from the 18th tee of a golf course. The green is placed 12.5 m below the tee. If the ball leaves the tee with a velocity of 45.0 m/s at an angle of 40 , what is the angle that the path of the ball makes with the green when the ball lands?
sub_question: What is the first step in answering any projectile question?
feedback_1: Equations come after setting up the situation.
feedback_2: Correct sketch to organize knowns/unknowns.
solution: $**1) What is the first step in answering any projectile question?** Resolve motion into horizontal and vertical components and write the kinematic equations for each (take (+\hat y) upward). --- **2) How are the equations of motion derived?** From constant-acceleration kinematics (Newton s second law) with gravity as the only acceleration. --- **3) What are the accelerations in projectile motion?** (;a_x=0,\qquad a_y=-g=-9.8~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **4) Which are the six equations of motion for any projectile?** Horizontal: (;x=v_{0x}t, v_x=v_{0x}, a_x=0.) Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity?** With (v_0=45.0~\mathrm{m/s}), (\theta=40^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos40^\circ\approx 34.47~\mathrm{m/s},\qquad v_{0y}=v_0\sin40^\circ\approx 28.93~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) What is the vertical component of velocity at the apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the time the ball is (12.5~\mathrm{m}) below the tee?** Use the vertical position with (\Delta y=-12.5~\mathrm{m}): [ -12.5=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2. ] --- **8) At what time does the ball strike the green?** Solve (\tfrac12 g t^2- v_{0y}t-12.5=0): [ t=\frac{v_{0y}+\sqrt{v_{0y}^2+2g(12.5)}}{g}\approx 6.31~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **9) Which equation would you use to solve for the vertical velocity at any given time?** (;v_y(t)=v_{0y}-gt.) --- **10) What is the vertical velocity when the ball hits the green?** [ v_y=v_{0y}-gt\approx 28.93-9.8(6.31)\approx -32.89~\mathrm{m/s} (\text{downward}). ] --- **11) What is the horizontal velocity when the ball hits the green?** (;v_x=v_{0x}\approx 34.47~\mathrm{m/s}) (constant). --- **12) How would you solve for the angle of impact of the ball on the green?** Use (\tan\phi=\dfrac{|v_y|}{v_x}); (\phi) is the angle the velocity makes **below** the horizontal (the green is horizontal). --- **13) What is the angle that the path of the ball makes with the green when the ball lands?** [ \phi=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{|{-32.89}|}{34.47}\right)\approx 43.7^\circ \text{(below horizontal)}. ] So the ball strikes the green at an angle of **about (44^\circ)** to the surface.$

sub_question: How are the equations of motion derived?
feedback_1: Displacement comes after velocity.
feedback_2: Correct: integrate $a!\to!v!\to!y$.
feedback_4: Tools help, but the physics gives the equations.

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity?** With (v_0=45.0~\mathrm{m/s}), (\theta=40^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos40^\circ\approx 34.47~\mathrm{m/s},\qquad v_{0y}=v_0\sin40^\circ\approx 28.93~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) What is the vertical component of velocity at the apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the time the ball is (12.5~\mathrm{m}) below the tee?** Use the vertical position with (\Delta y=-12.5~\mathrm{m}): [ -12.5=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2. ] --- **8) At what time does the ball strike the green?** Solve (\tfrac12 g t^2- v_{0y}t-12.5=0): [ t=\frac{v_{0y}+\sqrt{v_{0y}^2+2g(12.5)}}{g}\approx 6.31~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **9) Which equation would you use to solve for the vertical velocity at any given time?** (;v_y(t)=v_{0y}-gt.) --- **10) What is the vertical velocity when the ball hits the green?** [ v_y=v_{0y}-gt\approx 28.93-9.8(6.31)\approx -32.89~\mathrm{m/s} (\text{downward}). ] --- **11) What is the horizontal velocity when the ball hits the green?** (;v_x=v_{0x}\approx 34.47~\mathrm{m/s}) (constant). --- **12) How would you solve for the angle of impact of the ball on the green?** Use (\tan\phi=\dfrac{|v_y|}{v_x}); (\phi) is the angle the velocity makes **below** the horizontal (the green is horizontal). --- **13) What is the angle that the path of the ball makes with the green when the ball lands?** [ \phi=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{|{-32.89}|}{34.47}\right)\approx 43.7^\circ \text{(below horizontal)}. ] So the ball strikes the green at an angle of **about (44^\circ)** to the surface.$

Vertical: (;y=y_0+v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2, v_y=v_{0y}-gt, a_y=-g.) --- **5) What are the horizontal and vertical components of initial velocity?** With (v_0=45.0~\mathrm{m/s}), (\theta=40^\circ): [ v_{0x}=v_0\cos40^\circ\approx 34.47~\mathrm{m/s},\qquad v_{0y}=v_0\sin40^\circ\approx 28.93~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **6) What is the vertical component of velocity at the apex?** (;v_y=0.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the time the ball is (12.5~\mathrm{m}) below the tee?** Use the vertical position with (\Delta y=-12.5~\mathrm{m}): [ -12.5=v_{0y}t-\tfrac12gt^2. ] --- **8) At what time does the ball strike the green?** Solve (\tfrac12 g t^2- v_{0y}t-12.5=0): [ t=\frac{v_{0y}+\sqrt{v_{0y}^2+2g(12.5)}}{g}\approx 6.31~\mathrm{s}. ] --- **9) Which equation would you use to solve for the vertical velocity at any given time?** (;v_y(t)=v_{0y}-gt.) --- **10) What is the vertical velocity when the ball hits the green?** [ v_y=v_{0y}-gt\approx 28.93-9.8(6.31)\approx -32.89~\mathrm{m/s} (\text{downward}). ] --- **11) What is the horizontal velocity when the ball hits the green?** (;v_x=v_{0x}\approx 34.47~\mathrm{m/s}) (constant). --- **12) How would you solve for the angle of impact of the ball on the green?** Use (\tan\phi=\dfrac{|v_y|}{v_x}); (\phi) is the angle the velocity makes **below** the horizontal (the green is horizontal). --- **13) What is the angle that the path of the ball makes with the green when the ball lands?** [ \phi=\tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{|{-32.89}|}{34.47}\right)\approx 43.7^\circ \text{(below horizontal)}. ] So the ball strikes the green at an angle of **about (44^\circ)** to the surface.$

full_question: A boy on a bicycle is travelling at 10 m/s. What is the angular velocity of a point on the tire if its radius is 0.34 m?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?
feedback_1: No units don t match; that s not the speed relation.
feedback_2: Correct: $v_t=\omega r$.
feedback_4: That s tangential acceleration $a_t=\alpha r$, not speed.
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** Use rolling-without-slipping: (;\omega=\dfrac{v_t}{r}.) --- **2) What is the value of (v_t) (i.e., the tangential velocity)?** The bike s speed equals the rim s tangential speed: (;v_t=10~\mathrm{m/s}.) --- **3) What is the angular velocity of a point on the tire?** [ \omega=\frac{v_t}{r}=\frac{10}{0.34}\approx 29.4~\mathrm{rad/s}. ]$

full_question: A young girl is swinging a rock tied to a string of length 1.5 m. How much time would it take for the rock to cover an arc distance of 1.25 m if the tangential velocity is 25 m/s?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?
feedback_1: No units don t match.
feedback_2: Correct: $v_t=\omega r$.
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** Use rolling relation: (;\omega=\dfrac{v_t}{r}.) --- **2) What is the value of (v_t) (i.e., the tangential velocity)?** (v_t=25~\mathrm{m/s}.) --- **3) What is the angular velocity?** [ \omega=\frac{v_t}{r}=\frac{25}{1.5}\approx 16.67~\mathrm{rad/s}. ] --- **4) Which equation would you use to find the angular displacement?** Arc-length relation: (;\theta=\dfrac{s}{r}.) --- **5) What is the value of (s)?** (s=1.25~\mathrm{m}.) --- **6) What is the angular displacement travelled (i.e., (\theta))?** [ \theta=\frac{1.25}{1.5}\approx 0.833~\mathrm{rad}. ] --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the time it takes for the rock to cover the (1.25~\mathrm{m}) distance?** Uniform circular motion: (;t=\dfrac{\theta}{\omega}.) --- **8) How much time would it take for the rock to cover an arc distance of (1.25~\mathrm{m})?** [ t=\frac{\theta}{\omega}=\frac{0.833}{16.67}\approx 0.050~\mathrm{s}. ] So it takes **about (0.050~\mathrm{s})**.$

full_question: Joe Baseball steps up to the plate. Upon swinging, the tip of the bat (length = 1.1 m from the tip of the hands) follows an angular path, travelling an angular displacement of 0.8 radians in a time of 0.09 s (assume the hands to be the centre of rotation). What is the tangential velocity of the bat tip after the 0.09s?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?
feedback_1: Correct angular velocity is angle divided by time (units rad/s).
feedback_2: No multiplying by $t$ gives wrong units.
feedback_3: No this inverts the relation (units s/rad).
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** (;\omega=\dfrac{\Delta\theta}{\Delta t}.) --- **2) What is the angular velocity?** [ \omega=\frac{0.8~\text{rad}}{0.09~\text{s}} \approx 8.89~\text{rad/s}. ] --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the tangential velocity?** (;v_t=\omega r.) --- **4) What is the tangential velocity of the bat tip after the (0.09~\text{s})?** [ v_t=(8.89~\text{rad/s})(1.10~\text{m})\approx 9.78~\text{m/s}. ] So the bat tip s tangential speed is **about (9.8~\mathrm{m/s})**.$

full_question: Find the total linear acceleration of a point 0.2 m from the axis of rotation of a segment that has an angular acceleration of $100 rad/s^2$ and an angular velocity of 10 rad/s.
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration?
feedback_1: Correct: radial (centripetal) acceleration is $a_r=\omega^2 r$.
feedback_2: Missing the square on $\omega$.
feedback_4: That s the tangential acceleration relation, not radial.
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration?** (a_r=\omega^2 r.) --- **2) What is the radial acceleration?** (a_r=(10~\mathrm{rad/s})^2(0.2~\mathrm{m})=100\cdot0.2=20~\mathrm{m/s^2}) (toward the axis). --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the tangential acceleration?** (a_t=\alpha r.) --- **4) What is the tangential acceleration?** (a_t=(100~\mathrm{rad/s^2})(0.2~\mathrm{m})=20~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **5) What direction does tangential acceleration act with respect to the radial acceleration?** Perpendicular to (a_r) (along the tangent to the path). --- **6) How would you find the total linear acceleration?** Use the Pythagorean sum since (a_r\perp a_t): (a_T=\sqrt{a_r^2+a_t^2}.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the total linear acceleration?** (a_T=\sqrt{(\omega^2 r)^2+(\alpha r)^2}.) --- **8) What is the total linear acceleration?** (a_T=\sqrt{20^2+20^2}=20\sqrt{2}\approx 28.3~\mathrm{m/s^2}.)$

solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration?** (a_r=\omega^2 r.) --- **2) What is the radial acceleration?** (a_r=(10~\mathrm{rad/s})^2(0.2~\mathrm{m})=100\cdot0.2=20~\mathrm{m/s^2}) (toward the axis). --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the tangential acceleration?** (a_t=\alpha r.) --- **4) What is the tangential acceleration?** (a_t=(100~\mathrm{rad/s^2})(0.2~\mathrm{m})=20~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **5) What direction does tangential acceleration act with respect to the radial acceleration?** Perpendicular to (a_r) (along the tangent to the path). --- **6) How would you find the total linear acceleration?** Use the Pythagorean sum since (a_r\perp a_t): (a_T=\sqrt{a_r^2+a_t^2}.) --- **7) Which equation would you use to find the total linear acceleration?** (a_T=\sqrt{(\omega^2 r)^2+(\alpha r)^2}.) --- **8) What is the total linear acceleration?** (a_T=\sqrt{20^2+20^2}=20\sqrt{2}\approx 28.3~\mathrm{m/s^2}.)$

full_question: A steel ball of 0.01 m radius is rolled along a surface for a distance of 2 m in one second. What is the angular velocity of the ball?
sub_question: What is the tangential velocity of the ball?
feedback_1: $No use v=d/t=2/1=2 m/s; 0.02 is far too small.$
feedback_2: No 2 m in 1 s is 2 m/s, not 20 m/s.
feedback_4: $Correct rolling without slipping gives v=2 m/s.$
solution: $**1) What is the tangential velocity of the ball?** The ball travels (2~\mathrm{m}) in (1~\mathrm{s}), so [ v_t=\frac{\Delta s}{\Delta t}=\frac{2}{1}=2~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** Rolling without slipping: (;\omega=\dfrac{v_t}{r}.) --- **3) What is the angular velocity of the ball?** With (r=0.01~\mathrm{m}): [ \omega=\frac{2}{0.01}=200~\mathrm{rad/s}. ] So the ball s angular velocity is **(200~\mathrm{rad/s})**.$

full_question: A tennis ball travels horizontally forward at a rate of 25 m/s with backspin. If the radius of the ball is 0.03 m and the spin velocity is 100 rad/s, how fast is a point on the top of the ball going relative to the ground?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the tangential velocity?
feedback_1: No units don t match; not the speed relation.
feedback_2: Correct: $v_t=\omega r$.
feedback_4: That s tangential acceleration ($a_t=\alpha r$), not speed.
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the tangential velocity?** Use (;v_t=\omega r.) --- **2) What is the tangential velocity of a point on the surface of the ball?** [ v_t=\omega r=(100~\mathrm{rad/s})(0.03~\mathrm{m})=3.0~\mathrm{m/s}. ] --- **3) What is the velocity of the point on the top of the ball relative to the centre of the ball?** With **backspin**, the top point moves backward relative to the ball s forward motion: (;v_{\text{top|center}}=-3.0~\mathrm{m/s}.) --- **4) What is the velocity of the centre of the ball relative to the ground?** (;v_{\text{center|ground}}=+25~\mathrm{m/s}) (forward). --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the velocity of the point on the top of the ball relative to the ground?** Relative velocity: (;v_{\text{top|ground}}=v_{\text{center|ground}}+v_{\text{top|center}}.) --- **6) How fast is a point on the top of the ball going relative to the ground?** [ v_{\text{top|ground}}=25+(-3)=22~\mathrm{m/s} \text{(forward)}. ]$

full_question: The front chainset on a racing bicycle has 52 teeth and the rear sprocket has 13 teeth. How far does the cyclist travel with each revolution of the pedal if the radius of the wheel is 0.37 m?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the distance travelled in one revolution of the rear wheel?
feedback_1: Correct circumference of a circle is $2\pi r$.
feedback_2: That s half the circumference.
feedback_3: That s the diameter, not an arc length.
feedback_4: Too large by a factor of 2.
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the distance travelled in one revolution of the rear wheel?** Circumference: (;C=2\pi r.) --- **2) What is the distance travelled in one revolution of the rear wheel?** [ C=2\pi(0.37)=0.74\pi\approx 2.325~\text{m}. ] --- **3) How many times will the rear sprocket rotate with each revolution of the front chainset?** Gear ratio (=\dfrac{52}{13}=4). So the rear sprocket (and thus the wheel) rotates (4) times per pedal revolution. --- **4) How far does the cyclist travel with each revolution of the pedal ?** [ \text{Distance per pedal rev} = 4,C = 4(2.325)\approx 9.30~\text{m}. ] So the cyclist travels **about (9.3~\mathrm{m})** per pedal revolution.$

full_question: If a cyclist travelled 4 m for every pedal revolution, how fast would she be going at a cadence of 80 revolutions per minute? (put answer in m/s)
sub_question: What is the distance travelled with 80 revolutions?
feedback_1: No multiply 4 m/rev by 80 rev.
feedback_2: That s for a single revolution.
solution: $**1) What is the distance travelled with 80 revolutions?** Each revolution covers (4~\mathrm{m}), so in (80) rev: [ d = 80\times 4 = 320~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the velocity of the cyclist?** Use average speed: (;v=\dfrac{\text{distance}}{\text{time}}=\dfrac{d}{t}). (Here (t=60~\mathrm{s}) for (80~\text{rev/min}).) --- **3) How fast would she be going ?** [ v=\frac{320~\mathrm{m}}{60~\mathrm{s}}=\frac{16}{3}\approx 5.33~\mathrm{m/s}. ]$

solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the arc length?** Use the arc-length relation: $s=r\theta$ (with (\theta) in radians). --- **2) What is the arc length of the inside lane?** For a half-lap (semicircle, (\theta=\pi)): [ s_{\text{in}}=r_{\text{in}}\theta=(25)(\pi)=25\pi\approx 78.54~\text{m}. ] --- **3) What is the arc length of the outside lane?** [ s_{\text{out}}=r_{\text{out}}\theta=(30)(\pi)=30\pi\approx 94.25~\text{m}. ] --- **4) Which equation would you use to find the stagger?** Stagger = difference in arc lengths over the same angle: (;\Delta s=(r_{\text{out}}-r_{\text{in}})\theta.) --- **5) What should the stagger between the starting position of two runners be?** [ \Delta s=(30-25)\pi=5\pi\approx 15.71~\text{m}. ] So the stagger should be **about (15.7~\mathrm{m})** for a semicircular curve.

full_question: An automobile travels at a constant speed on a highway curve of 1000 m radius. If the radial acceleration is not to exceed 1.2 m/s , determine the maximum allowable speed ($v_t$).
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?
feedback_1: Correct centripetal (radial) acceleration is $a_r=\omega^2 r$.
feedback_2: No; missing the square on $\omega$.
feedback_3: No; $r$ shouldn t be squared here.
feedback_4: That s tangential acceleration $a_t=\alpha r$, not radial.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** From radial acceleration: $a_r=\omega^2 r \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}$. --- **2) What is the angular velocity?** $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{1.2}{1000}}=\sqrt{0.0012}\approx 0.0346~\text{rad/s}.$ --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the tangential velocity?** Use $v_t=\omega r$ (equivalently, $v_t=\sqrt{a_r r}$). --- **4) What is the maximum allowable speed ($v_t$)?** $v_t=\sqrt{(1.2)(1000)}=\sqrt{1200}\approx 34.6~\text{m/s}\approx 125~\text{km/h}.$

full_question: An exercise physiologist who wishes to separate blood plasma from serum requires a radial acceleration of 10g. How many revolutions per minute (rpm) are required if the centrifuge has a radius of 0.20 m ($1g = 9.81 m/s^2$)?
sub_question: What is the value of the radial acceleration?
feedback_1: Correct $10g=10\times 9.81=98.1, \text{m/s}^2$.
feedback_2: That s only $1g$, not $10g$.
feedback_3: That would be $100g$ ten times too large.
feedback_4: That s $0.1g$ ten times too small.
solution: $**1) What is the value of the radial acceleration?** (a_r = 10g = 10(9.81) = 98.1~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** From centripetal relation: (;a_r=\omega^2 r ;\Rightarrow; \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}.) --- **3) What is the angular velocity?** [ \omega=\sqrt{\frac{98.1}{0.20}}=\sqrt{490.5}\approx 22.15~\mathrm{rad/s}. ] --- **4) How many radians are in one revolution?** (2\pi~\text{rad}.) --- **5) How would you convert (\omega) to rpm?** [ \text{rpm}=\frac{\omega}{2\pi}\times 60. ] --- **6) How many revolutions per minute (rpm) are required?** [ \text{rpm}=\frac{22.15}{2\pi}\times 60 \approx 211~\text{rpm}. ] So the centrifuge should spin at **about (2.11\times 10^2 \text{rpm})**.$

full_question: A point on a rotating body has a tangential acceleration of $30 m/s^2$. If the body has an angular velocity of 6 rad/s and a total linear acceleration of $40 m/s^2$, what is the tangential velocity?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration?
feedback_1: No total satisfies $a_T^2=a_r^2+a_t^2$; solve for $a_r$.
feedback_2: Correct: $a_r^2=a_T^2-a_t^2$.
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the radial acceleration?** Use the Pythagorean sum of perpendicular components: (;a_T^2=a_r^2+a_t^2\Rightarrow a_r=\sqrt{a_T^2-a_t^2}.) --- **2) What is the value of the radial acceleration?** [ a_r=\sqrt{40^2-30^2}=\sqrt{1600-900}=\sqrt{700}\approx 26.46~\mathrm{m/s^2}. ] --- **3) Which equation would you use to find the radius?** Centripetal relation: (;a_r=\omega^2 r\Rightarrow r=\dfrac{a_r}{\omega^2}.) --- **4) What is the value of the radius?** [ r=\frac{26.46}{6^2}=\frac{26.46}{36}\approx 0.735~\mathrm{m}. ] --- **5) Which equation would you use to find the tangential velocity?** (;v_t=\omega r.) --- **6) What is the tangential velocity?** [ v_t=(6)(0.735)\approx 4.41~\mathrm{m/s}. ] So the tangential speed is **about (4.41~\mathrm{m/s})**.$

full_question: In order for a roller coaster to perform a loop, the radial acceleration must be equal to gravity ($9.81~\mathrm{m/s^2}$). How fast must it be going as it enters the loop if the radius of the loop is $25~\mathrm{m}$?
sub_question: What is the value of the radial acceleration?
feedback_1: Too high by a factor of $10$.
feedback_2: Correct: $a_r=g=9.81~\mathrm{m/s^2}$.
feedback_4: Too low by a factor of $10$.
solution: $**1) What is the value of the radial acceleration?** (a_r = g = 9.81~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** From centripetal relation: (a_r=\omega^2 r \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}.) --- **3) What is the angular velocity?** [ \omega=\sqrt{\frac{9.81}{25}}=\sqrt{0.3924}\approx 0.626~\mathrm{rad/s}. ] --- **4) Which equation would you use to find the tangential velocity?** (v_t=\omega r) (equivalently, (v_t=\sqrt{a_r r})). --- **5) How fast must it be going as it enters the loop?** [ v_t=\sqrt{(9.81)(25)}=\sqrt{245.25}\approx 15.67~\mathrm{m/s}. ]$

solution: $**1) What is the value of the radial acceleration?** (a_r = g = 9.81~\mathrm{m/s^2}.) --- **2) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** From centripetal relation: (a_r=\omega^2 r \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{a_r}{r}}.) --- **3) What is the angular velocity?** [ \omega=\sqrt{\frac{9.81}{25}}=\sqrt{0.3924}\approx 0.626~\mathrm{rad/s}. ] --- **4) Which equation would you use to find the tangential velocity?** (v_t=\omega r) (equivalently, (v_t=\sqrt{a_r r})). --- **5) How fast must it be going as it enters the loop?** [ v_t=\sqrt{(9.81)(25)}=\sqrt{245.25}\approx 15.67~\mathrm{m/s}. ]$

solution: $**1) What is the first step in solving any general kinematics questions?** Identify the relevant points and choose a reference direction; here, use the segment s centre of gravity (CoG) and compute its change in (x): (\Delta x = x_{\text{CoG},2}-x_{\text{CoG},1}) (positive to the right). --- **2) How would you solve for the (x) displacement value of the segment?** Use the CoG (x)-coordinates at Position 1 and Position 2: [ \Delta x = x_2 - x_1. ] --- **3) What is the (x) displacement value of the segment?** [ \Delta x = 1.836 - 1.197 = 0.639~\text{m}\quad (\text{to the right}). ]$

full_question: Proximal Joint: Position 1 $(1.103, 0.764)$; Position 2 $(1.672, 1.178)$. Distal Joint: Position 1 $(1.321, 1.099)$; Position 2 $(2.052, 1.302)$. Centre of Gravity: Position 1 $(1.197, 0.983)$; Position 2 $(1.836, 1.231)$. Calculate the resultant linear displacement of the centre of mass of the segment.
sub_question: How would you calculate the resultant linear displacement of the CoM of the segment?
option_1: Draw a table to represent the y values throughout the motion
option_2: use the pythagorean theorem (i.e., resultant$^2$ $=$ x-component$^2$ $+$ y-component$^2$)
option_4: Find the difference between the y values of the CoG between frames
feedback_1: No this only helps with the y-component, not the resultant.
feedback_2: Correct: $d=\sqrt{(\Delta x)^2+(\Delta y)^2}$.
feedback_3: No use sum of squares, not a product.
feedback_4: That s just $\Delta y$, not the resultant.
solution: $**1) How would you calculate the resultant linear displacement of the CoM of the segment?** Compute the change in (x) and (y) of the centre of mass (CoM) between positions, then take the Euclidean norm: [ \Delta x = x_2-x_1,\qquad \Delta y = y_2-y_1,\qquad s=\sqrt{(\Delta x)^2+(\Delta y)^2}. ] **2) What is the resultant linear displacement of the CoM of the segment?** [ \Delta x = 1.836-1.197 = 0.639~\text{m},\qquad \Delta y = 1.231-0.983 = 0.248~\text{m}, ] [ s=\sqrt{0.639^2+0.248^2}\approx \sqrt{0.408+0.0615}\approx \sqrt{0.4695}\approx 0.685~\text{m}. ] So, the CoM s resultant linear displacement is **about (0.685~\mathrm{m})**.$

option_1: Draw a table to represent the angles throughout the motion

solution: **1) How would you solve for the angle of the segment with respect to the horizontal?** Compute the proximal distal vector: ($\Delta x=x_d-x_p, \Delta y=y_d-y_p$). Find the horizontal-referenced angle ($\theta_h=\operatorname{atan2}(\Delta y, \Delta x)$), then convert to vertical: ($\theta_v=90^\circ-\theta_h$) (use absolute value per your convention). --- **2) What is the angle of the segment in Frame #1 with respect to $0^\circ$ (vertical)?** ($\theta_{v1}=56.9^\circ$) (given as the correct vertical-reference angle). --- **3) What is the angle of the segment in Frame #2 with respect to $0^\circ$ (vertical)?** ($\theta_{v2}=18.1^\circ$) (given as the correct vertical-reference angle). --- **4) What is the next step?** **sum** the vertical-reference angles to obtain total excursion: ($\Delta\theta=\theta_{v1}+\theta_{v2}$). --- **5) What is the angular displacement?** $[ \Delta\theta ;=; 56.9^\circ ;+; 18.1^\circ ;=; \boxed{75.0^\circ}. ]$

option_1: Draw a table to represent the y values throughout the motion
option_2: Use the pythagorean theorem to solve for the resultant vector

full_question: Proximal Joint: Position 1 $(3.0, 5.0)$; Position 2 $(7.0, 6.0)$. Distal Joint: Position 1 $(2.0, 3.0)$; Position 2 $(9.0, 7.0)$. Centre of Gravity: Position 1 $(2.5, 4.0)$; Position 2 $(8.0, 6.5)$. Calculate the resultant linear displacement of the centre of mass of the segment.
sub_question: How would you calculate the resultant linear displacement of the CoM of the segment?
option_1: Draw a table to represent the y values throughout the motion
option_2: use the pythagorean theorem (i.e., $\text{resultant}^2=(\Delta x)^2+(\Delta y)^2$)
option_4: Find the difference between the y values of the CoG between frames
feedback_1: Helpful for organization, but it doesn t compute the resultant.
feedback_2: Correct: use the Pythagorean theorem on the $\Delta x$ and $\Delta y$ components.
feedback_3: This multiplies components resultant comes from squaring and adding the components.

solution: $**1) How would you calculate the resultant linear displacement of the CoM of the segment?** Compute the change in (x) and (y) of the CoM between positions, then take the Euclidean norm: [ \Delta x=x_2-x_1, \Delta y=y_2-y_1, s=\sqrt{(\Delta x)^2+(\Delta y)^2}. ] **2) What is the resultant linear displacement of the CoM of the segment?** [ \Delta x=8.0-2.5=5.5~\text{m},\qquad \Delta y=6.5-4.0=2.5~\text{m}, ] [ s=\sqrt{5.5^2+2.5^2}=\sqrt{30.25+6.25}=\sqrt{36.50}\approx 6.04~\text{m}. ] So, the CoM s resultant linear displacement is **about (6.04~\mathrm{m})**.$

option_1: Draw a table to represent the angles throughout the motion
option_2: Use the pythagorean theorem to solve for the angle of the resultant vector

solution: **1) Define the segment direction (proximal distal) and the angle from the horizontal** $\Delta x = x_d - x_p, \Delta y = y_d - y_p, \theta = \operatorname{atan2}(\Delta y, \Delta x) \text{(deg)}.$ --- **Frame #1 (P1 Prox $(3.0,5.0)$, Dist $(2.0,3.0)$)** $\Delta x_1 = 2.0 - 3.0 = -1.0, \Delta y_1 = 3.0 - 5.0 = -2.0.$ $\phi_1 = \tan^{-1}!\left(\left|\frac{\Delta y_1}{\Delta x_1}\right|\right) = \tan^{-1}(2) = 63.435^\circ.$ Since $(\Delta x_1, \Delta y_1)$ is in QIII, $\theta_1 = 180^\circ + \phi_1 = 180^\circ + 63.435^\circ = 243.435^\circ \approx 243.43^\circ.$ (Alt: $\operatorname{atan2}(-2,-1) = -116.565^\circ \Rightarrow \theta_1 = -116.565^\circ + 360^\circ = 243.435^\circ$.) --- **Frame #2 (P2 Prox $(7.0,6.0)$, Dist $(9.0,7.0)$)** $\Delta x_2 = 9.0 - 7.0 = 2.0, \Delta y_2 = 7.0 - 6.0 = 1.0.$ Quadrant I: $\theta_2 = \tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{\Delta y_2}{\Delta x_2}\right) = \tan^{-1}!\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) = 26.565^\circ \approx 26.57^\circ.$ --- **Sum of the angles (your convention)** $\Delta \theta = \theta_1 + \theta_2 = 243.435^\circ + 26.565^\circ = 270.000^\circ.$ So, the segment s total angular displacement is **$270.00^\circ$**.

solution: **1) How would you solve for the angle of the segment with respect to the horizontal?** Form the vector from Proximal ((x_p,y_p)) to Distal ((x_d,y_d)): ($\Delta x=x_d-x_p, \Delta y=y_d-y_p$). Then ($\theta=\operatorname{atan2}(\Delta y, \Delta x)$) measured from the (0^\circ) (positive (x)) axis. --- **2) What is the angle of the segment in Frame #1 with respect to $0^\circ$?** P1 Prox ((1.50,0.80)), Dist ((1.60,0.60)) (\Rightarrow) ($\Delta x_1=0.10, \Delta y_1=-0.20$). ($\theta_1=\operatorname{atan2}(-0.20,0.10)\approx -63.43^\circ$). --- **3) What is the angle of the segment in Frame #2 with respect to $0^\circ$?** P2 Prox ((1.57,0.89)), Dist ((1.53,0.67)) (\Rightarrow) ($\Delta x_2=-0.04, \Delta y_2=-0.22$). ($\theta_2=\operatorname{atan2}(-0.22,-0.04)\approx -100.30^\circ$). --- **4) What is the next step?** Compute the signed angular displacement using a consistent reference: ($\Delta\theta=\theta_2-\theta_1$). --- **5) What is the angular displacement?** ($\Delta\theta=-100.30^\circ - (-63.43^\circ)= -36.87^\circ$). Thus, the segment rotated **($36.87^\circ$) clockwise** (negative sign indicates clockwise rotation).

full_question: What is the angular velocity of the thigh if the length of the thigh is $0.45, \text{m}$?
sub_question: In a knee hip segment, the final linear velocity of the knee with respect to the ground is equal to
feedback_1: No $\overrightarrow{V_{H/H}}=\vec{0}$; you need $\overrightarrow{V_{H/G}}$.
feedback_2: Correct: relative velocity addition $\overrightarrow{V_{K/G}}=\overrightarrow{V_{K/H}}+\overrightarrow{V_{H/G}}$.
feedback_4: You ve double-counted the ground term.
solution: **1) In a knee hip segment, the final linear velocity of the knee with respect to the ground is equal to ** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}+\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{H}}.$ --- **2) How do you rewrite the equation to solve for (\overrightarrow{V_{K/H}})?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{H}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}-\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}.$ --- **3) Rewrite for components.** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{H}, x}&=V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}-V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}, V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{H}, y}&=V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}-V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}. \end{aligned}$ --- **4) What are the component velocities of (\vec{V}*{K/G}) (given (|\vec V*{K/G}|=2.044~\text{m/s}) at (11.86^\circ))?** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=2.044\cos 11.86^\circ \approx **4) What are the component velocities of (\vec{V}*{K/G}) (given (|\vec V*{K/G}|=2.044~\text{m/s}) at (11.86^\circ))?** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=2.044\cos 11.86^\circ \approx 2.000~\text{m/s}, V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=2.044\sin 11.86^\circ \approx 0.420~\text{m/s}. \end{aligned}$ --- **5) What is the next step?** Subtract the hip s ground-relative velocity components ((V_{H/Gx}=1.4~\text{m/s},;V_{H/Gy}=-0.15~\text{m/s})). --- **6) What is (V_{K/Hx})?** $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{H}, x}=2.000-1.4=0.600~\text{m/s}.$ **7) What is (V_{K/Hy})?** $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{H}, y}=0.420-(-0.15)=0.570~\text{m/s}.$ --- **8) How would you solve for the resultant speed (V_{K/H})?** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{H}}=\sqrt{V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{H}, x}^2+V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{H}, y}^2}.$ **9) What is the resultant linear speed (V_{K/H})?** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{H}}=\sqrt{0.600^2+0.570^2}\approx 0.828~\text{m/s}.$ --- **10) Which equation relates linear and angular speed?** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{H}}=\omega, r.$ --- **11) What is the angular velocity of the thigh?** With (r=0.45~\text{m}): $\omega=\frac{\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{H}}}{r}=\frac{0.828}{0.45}\approx 1.84~\text{rad/s}.$

full_question: Find the magnitude of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}$ if $\omega$ is $20, \text{rad/s}$ and the length of the leg is $0.4, \text{m}$.
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?
feedback_1: No $v=\omega t$ mixes linear speed with time.
feedback_2: No $\omega^2 r$ gives radial acceleration, not speed.
feedback_4: No $v=\theta/t$ is angular speed, not linear.
solution: $**1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** Use the linear angular relation: (;V_{A/K}=\omega r.) --- **2) What is the magnitude of (V_{A/K})?** [ V_{A/K}=\omega r=(20 \text{rad/s})(0.40 \text{m})=8.0 \text{m/s}. ]$

full_question: If the velocity of the ankle ($A$) is $7, \mathrm{m/s}$, $28^\circ$ below horizontal, and the knee is not moving, what must $q$ be?
sub_question: At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the lower leg?
feedback_1: Tangential (linear) velocity is perpendicular to the segment, not $65^\circ$.
feedback_2: Being colinear ($180^\circ$) is incorrect; it must be perpendicular.
feedback_3: Correct: tangential velocity acts at $90^\circ$ to the radius (the lower leg).
feedback_4: $45^\circ$ is not guaranteed; the correct relation is perpendicular ($90^\circ$).
solution: $**1) At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the lower leg?** Perpendicular to the segment: the ankle s tangential velocity is (90^\circ) to the lower leg. --- **2) What is the value of (q)?** The ankle s velocity is (28^\circ) **below** horizontal, so the leg must be oriented (90^\circ) from that direction: [ q = 90^\circ - 28^\circ = 62^\circ \text{(above horizontal)}. ]$

full_question: If $q=50^\circ$, $\omega=10 \mathrm{rad/s}$, $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{G}}=12 \mathrm{m/s}$ (at $8^\circ$ below horizontal), and the leg length is $r=0.4 \mathrm{m}$, find the magnitude of the linear velocity of the knee w.r.t. the ground.
sub_question: In an ankle knee segment, the final linear velocity of the **knee** w.r.t. ground equals?
feedback_1: Not quite: this would add the relative and absolute velocities in the wrong direction.
feedback_2: Not the correct segment pair for this problem.
feedback_3: Correct: relative motion of $K$ to $A$ subtracted from $A$ to ground, $ \mathbf \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}=\mathbf \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{G}}-\mathbf \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}$.
feedback_4: The RHS is dimensionally odd and tautological.
solution: **1) In an ankle knee segment, the final linear velocity of the knee w.r.t. ground equals?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{G}}-\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}.$ **2) Rewrite to solve explicitly for (\mathbf V_{K/G}).** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}=\langle V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, x}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, x},; V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, y}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, y}\rangle.$ **3) Account for components.** $V_x=V\cos\theta, \qquad V_y=V\sin\theta.$ **4) Components of (\mathbf V_{A/G}) ((12~\mathrm{m/s}) at (-8^\circ)):** $V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, x}=12\cos(-8^\circ)\approx 11.883 \mathrm{m/s}, \qquad V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, y}=12\sin(-8^\circ)\approx -1.670 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **5) Tangential speed relation:** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}=\omega r.$ **6) Magnitude of (V_{A/K}):** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}=(10)(0.4)=4.0 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **7) Components of (\mathbf V_{A/K}) (with (q=50^\circ\Rightarrow \mathbf V_{A/K}) at (-40^\circ)):** $V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, x}=4\cos(-40^\circ)\approx 3.064 \mathrm{m/s}, \qquad V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, y}=4\sin(-40^\circ)\approx -2.571 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **8) Knee components and resultant:** $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}=V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, x}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, x}=11.883-3.064=8.819 \mathrm{m/s},$ $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}=V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, y}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, y}=-1.670-(-2.571)=0.901 \mathrm{m/s},$ $\left|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}\right|=\sqrt{V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}^2+V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}^2}=\sqrt{8.819^2+0.901^2}\approx 8.86 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **9) What is $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}$?** [ V_{K/Gx}=V_{A/Gx}-V_{A/Kx} =11.883-3.064 =8.819~\mathrm{m/s}. ] **10) What is $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}$?** [ V_{K/Gy}=V_{A/Gy}-V_{A/Ky} =-1.670-(-2.571) =0.901~\mathrm{m/s}. ] **11) Final: magnitude of (\mathbf V_{K/G}) (numeric entry).** [ \left|\vec V_{K/G}\right| =\sqrt{V_{K/Gx}^{,2}+V_{K/Gy}^{,2}} =\sqrt{8.819^{2}+0.901^{2}} \approx 8.86~\mathrm{m/s}. ]

solution: **1) In an ankle knee segment, the final linear velocity of the knee w.r.t. ground equals?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{G}}-\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}.$ **2) Rewrite to solve explicitly for (\mathbf V_{K/G}).** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}=\langle V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, x}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, x},; V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, y}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, y}\rangle.$ **3) Account for components.** $V_x=V\cos\theta, \qquad V_y=V\sin\theta.$ **4) Components of (\mathbf V_{A/G}) ((12~\mathrm{m/s}) at (-8^\circ)):** $V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, x}=12\cos(-8^\circ)\approx 11.883 \mathrm{m/s}, \qquad V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, y}=12\sin(-8^\circ)\approx -1.670 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **5) Tangential speed relation:** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}=\omega r.$ **6) Magnitude of (V_{A/K}):** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{A}}/\mathrm{K}}=(10)(0.4)=4.0 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **7) Components of (\mathbf V_{A/K}) (with (q=50^\circ\Rightarrow \mathbf V_{A/K}) at (-40^\circ)):** $V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, x}=4\cos(-40^\circ)\approx 3.064 \mathrm{m/s}, \qquad V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, y}=4\sin(-40^\circ)\approx -2.571 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **8) Knee components and resultant:** $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}=V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, x}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, x}=11.883-3.064=8.819 \mathrm{m/s},$ $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}=V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, y}-V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{K}, y}=-1.670-(-2.571)=0.901 \mathrm{m/s},$ $\left|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{K}}/\mathrm{G}}\right|=\sqrt{V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}^2+V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}^2}=\sqrt{8.819^2+0.901^2}\approx 8.86 \mathrm{m/s}.$ **9) What is $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, x}$?** [ V_{K/Gx}=V_{A/Gx}-V_{A/Kx} =11.883-3.064 =8.819~\mathrm{m/s}. ] **10) What is $V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{G}, y}$?** [ V_{K/Gy}=V_{A/Gy}-V_{A/Ky} =-1.670-(-2.571) =0.901~\mathrm{m/s}. ] **11) Final: magnitude of (\mathbf V_{K/G}) (numeric entry).** [ \left|\vec V_{K/G}\right| =\sqrt{V_{K/Gx}^{,2}+V_{K/Gy}^{,2}} =\sqrt{8.819^{2}+0.901^{2}} \approx 8.86~\mathrm{m/s}. ]

full_question: Calculate the magnitude of the tangential velocity of the wrist about the elbow.
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?
feedback_1: Incorrect multiplying by $t$ gives angle ($\theta=\omega t$), not speed.
feedback_2: Incorrect $, \omega^{2}r,$ is centripetal acceleration, not velocity.
feedback_4: Incorrect $q/t$ is angular velocity, not linear speed.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** Use the linear angular relation for tangential speed: $(;v_{W/E}=\omega r.)$ **2) What is the magnitude of $(v_{W/E})$?** [ $v_{W/E}=\omega r=(4.8 \text{rad/s})(0.25 \text{m})=1.20 \text{m/s}$. ]

full_question: Calculate the magnitude of the tangential velocity of the wrist about the elbow.
sub_question: What is the magnitude of $v_{W/E}$?
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the angular velocity?** Use the linear angular relation for tangential speed: $(;v_{W/E}=\omega r.)$ **2) What is the magnitude of $(v_{W/E})$?** [ $v_{W/E}=\omega r=(4.8 \text{rad/s})(0.25 \text{m})=1.20 \text{m/s}$. ]

full_question: At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the horizontal?
sub_question: At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the elbow?
feedback_1: Incorrect: tangential velocity is perpendicular to the radius, not $65^\circ$.
feedback_2: Incorrect: $180^\circ$ is colinear, not perpendicular.
feedback_3: Correct: tangential velocity acts $90^\circ$ to the radius (forearm).
feedback_4: Incorrect: $45^\circ$ is not guaranteed by geometry.
solution: $**1) At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the horizontal?** Tangential velocity is perpendicular to the forearm. The forearm is (23^\circ) from vertical (\Rightarrow) (67^\circ) from horizontal, so the tangential direction is (90^\circ-67^\circ=23^\circ) to the horizontal (sign depends on rotation). [ \theta_{\text{tan|hor}} = 90^\circ - (90^\circ - 23^\circ) = 23^\circ. ] --- **2) At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the elbow (forearm)?** [ \theta_{\text{tan|segment}} = 90^\circ. ] --- **3) At what angle does (V_{W/E}) act with respect to the horizontal?** [ \boxed{\theta_{V_{W/E},|\text{hor}} = 23^\circ} ] (above or below the horizontal depending on the direction of (,\omega,)).$

full_question: At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the horizontal?
sub_question: At what angle does $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}$ act with respect to the horizontal?
solution: $**1) At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the horizontal?** Tangential velocity is perpendicular to the forearm. The forearm is (23^\circ) from vertical (\Rightarrow) (67^\circ) from horizontal, so the tangential direction is (90^\circ-67^\circ=23^\circ) to the horizontal (sign depends on rotation). [ \theta_{\text{tan|hor}} = 90^\circ - (90^\circ - 23^\circ) = 23^\circ. ] --- **2) At what angle does the tangential velocity act with respect to the elbow (forearm)?** [ \theta_{\text{tan|segment}} = 90^\circ. ] --- **3) At what angle does (V_{W/E}) act with respect to the horizontal?** [ \boxed{\theta_{V_{W/E},|\text{hor}} = 23^\circ} ] (above or below the horizontal depending on the direction of (,\omega,)).$

full_question: Calculate the velocity of the wrist with respect to the ground.
sub_question: In a wrist elbow segment, the final linear velocity of the wrist with respect to the ground is equal to?
feedback_1: Sum the wrist s velocity relative to the elbow with the elbow s velocity relative to ground.
feedback_2: This rearranges the unknown onto both sides.
feedback_4: Adds the elbow s velocity to itself, not the relative wrist term.
solution: **1) In a wrist elbow segment, the final linear velocity of the wrist with respect to the ground is equal to?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{G}}+\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}.$ --- **2) How would you rewrite the equation to account for the x and y directions of the velocities?** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, x}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x}, V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, y}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, y}. \end{aligned}$ --- **3) What are the x and y component velocities of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** Speed (=5,\mathrm{m/s}) at (37^\circ) above horizontal $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=5\cos37^\circ\approx 3.99~\mathrm{m/s}, V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=5\sin37^\circ\approx 3.01~\mathrm{m/s}. \end{aligned}$ --- **4) What are the x and y component velocities of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}$?** Tangential speed from earlier: $v_{W/E}=\omega r=(4.8)(0.25)=1.20~\mathrm{m/s}$. Direction of tangential velocity is (23^\circ) from horizontal (perpendicular to the forearm), so $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x}&=1.20\cos23^\circ\approx 1.105~\mathrm{m/s}, V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, y}&=1.20\sin23^\circ\approx 0.469~\mathrm{m/s}. \end{aligned}$ --- **5) What is the next step?** Add components to get the wrist s ground relative components. --- **6) What is the value of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{GX}}$?** $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}=3.99+1.105\approx 5.10~\mathrm{m/s}.$ **7) What is the value of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{GY}}$?** $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, y}=3.01+0.469\approx 3.48~\mathrm{m/s}.$ --- **8) How would you solve for the resultant velocity?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}^{,2}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, y}^{,2}}.$ --- **9) What is the resultant velocity $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{(5.10)^2+(3.48)^2}\approx \sqrt{38.1}\approx 6.17~\mathrm{m/s}.$ (Directed at angle (\tan^{-1}(3.48/5.10)\approx 34^\circ) above horizontal.)

feedback_1: Uses wrong terms and duplicates.
feedback_2: Mixes frames.
solution: **1) In a wrist elbow segment, the final linear velocity of the wrist with respect to the ground is equal to?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{G}}+\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}.$ --- **2) How would you rewrite the equation to account for the x and y directions of the velocities?** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, x}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x}, V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, y}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, y}. \end{aligned}$ --- **3) What are the x and y component velocities of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** Speed (=5,\mathrm{m/s}) at (37^\circ) above horizontal $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=5\cos37^\circ\approx 3.99~\mathrm{m/s}, V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=5\sin37^\circ\approx 3.01~\mathrm{m/s}. \end{aligned}$ --- **4) What are the x and y component velocities of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}$?** Tangential speed from earlier: $v_{W/E}=\omega r=(4.8)(0.25)=1.20~\mathrm{m/s}$. Direction of tangential velocity is (23^\circ) from horizontal (perpendicular to the forearm), so $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x}&=1.20\cos23^\circ\approx 1.105~\mathrm{m/s}, V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, y}&=1.20\sin23^\circ\approx 0.469~\mathrm{m/s}. \end{aligned}$ --- **5) What is the next step?** Add components to get the wrist s ground relative components. --- **6) What is the value of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{GX}}$?** $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}=3.99+1.105\approx 5.10~\mathrm{m/s}.$ **7) What is the value of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{GY}}$?** $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, y}=3.01+0.469\approx 3.48~\mathrm{m/s}.$ --- **8) How would you solve for the resultant velocity?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}^{,2}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, y}^{,2}}.$ --- **9) What is the resultant velocity $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{(5.10)^2+(3.48)^2}\approx \sqrt{38.1}\approx 6.17~\mathrm{m/s}.$ (Directed at angle (\tan^{-1}(3.48/5.10)\approx 34^\circ) above horizontal.)

full_question: What is the velocity of the hand with respect to the ground if the arm angle is 65 ?
sub_question: In a hand shoulder segment, the final linear velocity of the hand with respect to the ground is equal to?
feedback_1: A: Uses wrong relative term.
feedback_2: B: Circular definition.
solution: **1) In a hand shoulder segment, the final linear velocity of the hand with respect to the ground is equal to?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{S}}/\mathrm{G}}+\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}.$ --- **2) How would you rewrite the equations to account for the x and y directions of the velocities?** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}+V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, x}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, y}+V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, y}. \end{aligned}$ --- **3) What are the x and y-component velocities of $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{S}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** Given $2~\mathrm{m/s}$ to the right: $V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}=2.00~\mathrm{m/s}, \qquad V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, y}=0.$ --- **4) Which equation would you use to find tangential velocity?** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}=\omega r.$ --- **5) What are the x and y-component velocities of $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}$?** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}= \omega r=(18)(0.6)=10.8~\mathrm{m/s}.$ For arm angle $q=65^\circ$, the tangential direction is perpendicular to the arm. Assuming **clockwise** rotation (as sketched), $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}$ is at $q-90^\circ=-25^\circ$ from $+x$: $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, x}&=10.8\cos(-25^\circ)\approx 9.79~\mathrm{m/s}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, y}&=10.8\sin(-25^\circ)\approx -4.56~\mathrm{m/s}. \end{aligned}$ --- **6) What is the next step?** Add components. --- **7) What is the value of $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}$?** $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}=2.00+9.79\approx 11.79~\mathrm{m/s}.$ **8) What is the value of $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}$?** $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}=0+(-4.56)\approx -4.56~\mathrm{m/s}.$ --- **9) How would you solve for the resultant velocity?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}^{,2}+V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}^{,2}}.$ --- **10) What is the magnitude of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{(11.79)^2+(-4.56)^2}\approx 12.6~\mathrm{m/s}.$ *(If the rotation were counter-clockwise instead, use $q+90^\circ$; you d get $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}|\approx 9.0~\mathrm{m/s}$.)*

full_question: What is the velocity of the hand with respect to the ground if the arm angle is 65 ?
sub_question: How would you rewrite the equations to account for the x and y directions of the velocities?
option_1: $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{H}, x}+V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{H}, x}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}=V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, y}+V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{S}, y}$
option_2: $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}+V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{H}, x}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}=V_{\mathrm{A}/\mathrm{G}, y}+V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{W}, y}$
option_3: $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}=V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, x}+V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}=V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, y}+V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, y}$
option_4: $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}=V_{\mathrm{G}/\mathrm{A}, x}+V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{A}, x}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}=V_{\mathrm{G}/\mathrm{A}, y}+V_{\mathrm{K}/\mathrm{A}, y}$
feedback_1: A: Nonsense terms.
feedback_2: B: Wrong bodies/axes.
solution: **1) In a hand shoulder segment, the final linear velocity of the hand with respect to the ground is equal to?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{S}}/\mathrm{G}}+\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}.$ --- **2) How would you rewrite the equations to account for the x and y directions of the velocities?** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}+V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, x}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, y}+V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, y}. \end{aligned}$ --- **3) What are the x and y-component velocities of $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{S}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** Given $2~\mathrm{m/s}$ to the right: $V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}=2.00~\mathrm{m/s}, \qquad V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, y}=0.$ --- **4) Which equation would you use to find tangential velocity?** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}=\omega r.$ --- **5) What are the x and y-component velocities of $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}$?** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}= \omega r=(18)(0.6)=10.8~\mathrm{m/s}.$ For arm angle $q=65^\circ$, the tangential direction is perpendicular to the arm. Assuming **clockwise** rotation (as sketched), $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{S}}$ is at $q-90^\circ=-25^\circ$ from $+x$: $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, x}&=10.8\cos(-25^\circ)\approx 9.79~\mathrm{m/s}, V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{S}, y}&=10.8\sin(-25^\circ)\approx -4.56~\mathrm{m/s}. \end{aligned}$ --- **6) What is the next step?** Add components. --- **7) What is the value of $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}$?** $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}=2.00+9.79\approx 11.79~\mathrm{m/s}.$ **8) What is the value of $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}$?** $V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}=0+(-4.56)\approx -4.56~\mathrm{m/s}.$ --- **9) How would you solve for the resultant velocity?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, x}^{,2}+V_{\mathrm{H}/\mathrm{G}, y}^{,2}}.$ --- **10) What is the magnitude of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}$?** $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}|=\sqrt{(11.79)^2+(-4.56)^2}\approx 12.6~\mathrm{m/s}.$ *(If the rotation were counter-clockwise instead, use $q+90^\circ$; you d get $|\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{H}}/\mathrm{G}}|\approx 9.0~\mathrm{m/s}$.)*

feedback_2: This reverses a term and omits the shoulder s ground velocity.
feedback_4: Missing the wrist elbow term and mixes frames.
solution: **1) In a wrist elbow shoulder segment, the final linear velocity of the wrist with respect to the ground is equal to?** $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{G}}=\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{S}}/\mathrm{G}}+\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{S}}+\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}.$ --- **2) How would you rewrite the equation to account for x and y components?** $\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}&=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}+V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{S}, x}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x}, V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, y}&=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, y}+V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{S}, y}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, y}. \end{aligned}$ --- **3) Which equation would you use to find a tangential linear speed from angular speed?** $;V_{\text{tangential}}=\omega r.$ --- **4) What is the magnitude of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}$? (Given $\omega_F=56~\mathrm{rad/s}, EW=0.23~\mathrm{m}$)** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}=\omega_F, EW=(56)(0.23)=12.88~\mathrm{m/s}.$ The wrist about elbow velocity is **perpendicular** to the forearm (right-angle marker). --- **5) What is the value of $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x}$?** Forearm (\perp) $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}$ and is taken nearly along the javelin ( horizontal), so $\vec \overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{W}}/\mathrm{E}}$ is vertical (\Rightarrow) $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x}=0~\mathrm{m/s}.$ --- **6) What is the magnitude of $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{S}}$? (Given $\omega_A=65~\mathrm{rad/s}, SE=0.26~\mathrm{m}$)** $\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{S}}=\omega_A, SE=(65)(0.26)=16.90~\mathrm{m/s}.$ --- **7) What is the value of $V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{S}, x}$?** Upper arm makes $110^\circ$ with (+x); tangential direction is $110^\circ+90^\circ=200^\circ$. $V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{S}, x}=\overrightarrow{V_{\mathrm{E}}/\mathrm{S}}\cos 200^\circ=16.90\cos 200^\circ\approx 16.90(-0.9397)\approx -15.9~\mathrm{m/s}.$ --- **8) What is the next step?** Add horizontal components with the shoulder s forward speed $V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}=8.5~\mathrm{m/s}$. --- **9) What is the horizontal velocity of the wrist $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}$?** $V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{G}, x}=V_{\mathrm{S}/\mathrm{G}, x}+V_{\mathrm{E}/\mathrm{S}, x}+V_{\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{E}, x} =8.5+(-15.9)+0\approx -7.4~\mathrm{m/s}.$ So the wrist s horizontal velocity is **$\boxed{7.4~\mathrm{m/s}}$ backward** (negative (x); magnitude (7.4~\mathrm{m/s})).

full_question: What is the moment of force about the axis?
sub_question: What is the moment arm (d )?
option_1: The perpendicular distance between the axis and the line of action of the force
option_2: The distance from the axis to the point of force application
option_3: Half the perpendicular distance between the axis and the force
feedback_1: Correct this is the definition of the moment arm.
feedback_2: This is just the radius to the point, not the perpendicular distance.
feedback_4: This is unrelated to the definition.
solution: **1) What is the moment arm ((d_\perp))?** $d_\perp=r\sin\theta=(0.75~\text{m})\sin 30^\circ=0.375~\text{m}$. **2) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M=F,d_\perp\quad\text{(equivalently }M=rF\sin\theta\text{)}$. **3) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of the $150~\text{N}$ force?** $d_\perp=r\sin\theta$. **4) How would you find whether this moment of force is positive or negative?** Use the right-hand rule: counterclockwise (\Rightarrow) $M>0$, clockwise (\Rightarrow) $M<0$. Here the force causes counterclockwise rotation (\Rightarrow) $M>0$. **5) What is the moment of force about the axis?** $M=F,d_\perp=(150~\text{N})(0.375~\text{m})=56.25~\text{N\cdot m}$. So the moment is **(+56.25~\text{N m})**.

solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M=F,d_\perp\quad(\text{equivalently }M=rF\sin\theta)$. **2) What is the correct diagram for the 600 N force?** A. **3) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of the 600 N force?** $d_{\perp,600}=l\cos 40^\circ=(0.261)\cos 40^\circ$. **4) What is the moment of force caused by the 600 N force?** $M_{600}=F,d_{\perp,600}=600,(0.261\cos 40^\circ)\approx 1.20\times10^2~\text{N m}$ (counter-clockwise, (+)). **5) What is the correct diagram for the 2000 N force?** D. **6) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M=F,d_\perp$. **7) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of the 2000 N force?** $d_{\perp,2000}=l\cos 40^\circ=(0.065)\cos 40^\circ$. **8) What is the moment of force caused by the 2000 N force?** $M_{2000}=2000,(0.065\cos 40^\circ)\approx 1.00\times10^2~\text{N m}$ (clockwise, (-)). **9) How would you find the total moment of force on the ankle?** $M_{\text{total}}=M_{600}+M_{2000}$. **10) What is the moment of force acting on the ankle?** $M_{\text{total}}\approx(+120)-100=+20~\text{N m}$ (counter-clockwise).

full_question: What is the length of the moment arm (MA) of force F about the knee joint?
sub_question: How would you find the distance between the axis and where the force acts?
feedback_1: That distance is the hypotenuse of a right triangle formed by 0.4 m and 0.1 m; use Pythagoras.
feedback_2: Cross products give torque directly; unnecessary for just the distance.
solution: **1) How would you find the distance between the axis and where the force acts?** $ l=\sqrt{(0.4)^2+(0.1)^2}=\sqrt{0.16+0.01}=\sqrt{0.17}\approx 0.412~\text{m}. $ **2) Which is the correct diagram?** B. **3) What is the distance between the axis and where the force acts?** $ l\approx 0.412~\text{m}. $ **4) Given this diagram What is the value of angle $f$?** $ \tan f=\frac{0.1}{0.4}=0.25 ;\Rightarrow; f=\tan^{-1}(0.25)\approx 14^\circ. $ **5) Given this diagram What is the value of angle $q$?** $ q=90^\circ-f\approx 90^\circ-14^\circ=76^\circ. $ **6) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm between the axis and the force?** $ ma=l\sin\phi,\qquad \phi=\big|,q-38^\circ,\big|=\big|,76^\circ-38^\circ,\big|=38^\circ. $ **7) What is the length of the moment arm $(ma)$?** $ ma=l\sin\phi=(0.412)\sin 38^\circ \approx 0.412\times 0.6157 \approx 0.254~\text{m}. $

solution: **1) How would you find the distance between the axis and where the force acts?** $ l=\sqrt{(0.4)^2+(0.1)^2}=\sqrt{0.16+0.01}=\sqrt{0.17}\approx 0.412~\text{m}. $ **2) Which is the correct diagram?** B. **3) What is the distance between the axis and where the force acts?** $ l\approx 0.412~\text{m}. $ **4) Given this diagram What is the value of angle $f$?** $ \tan f=\frac{0.1}{0.4}=0.25 ;\Rightarrow; f=\tan^{-1}(0.25)\approx 14^\circ. $ **5) Given this diagram What is the value of angle $q$?** $ q=90^\circ-f\approx 90^\circ-14^\circ=76^\circ. $ **6) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm between the axis and the force?** $ ma=l\sin\phi,\qquad \phi=\big|,q-38^\circ,\big|=\big|,76^\circ-38^\circ,\big|=38^\circ. $ **7) What is the length of the moment arm $(ma)$?** $ ma=l\sin\phi=(0.412)\sin 38^\circ \approx 0.412\times 0.6157 \approx 0.254~\text{m}. $

full_question: If the magnitude of force A is 150 N, what is the moment of force of A about the axis?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?
feedback_1: $a$ is not the (perpendicular) distance; this doesn t yield torque.
feedback_2: Correct: torque equals force times the perpendicular moment arm $d_\perp$.
feedback_3: Dividing by distance is incorrect for torque.
feedback_4: Velocity $v$ is unrelated to static moment.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M=F,d_\perp \quad (\text{equivalently } M=rF\sin\phi)$. **2) Which is the correct diagram?** A. **3) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of the $150~\text{N}$ force?** The radius from the axis is vertical with length $l=0.06~\text{m}$. The force is at $40^\circ$ above the horizontal, so the angle between the radius and the force is $\phi=90^\circ-40^\circ=50^\circ$; hence [ d_\perp=l\sin\phi=l\sin 50^\circ=l\cos 40^\circ. ] **4) How would you find whether this moment of force is positive or negative?** Use the right-hand rule: the force s leftward component at the point **below** the axis produces a **clockwise** rotation (\Rightarrow) $M<0$ (with the CCW-positive convention). **5) What is the moment of force about the axis?** [ d_\perp=0.06\cos 40^\circ\approx 0.04596~\text{m}, ] [ M=F,d_\perp=(150)(0.04596)\approx 6.89~\text{N m}. ] So the moment is **$-6.9~\text{N m}$** (clockwise).

full_question: If the magnitude of force B is 100 N, what is the moment of force of B about the axis?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?
feedback_1: a isn t a moment arm.
feedback_2: Correct: $M = F d_\perp$.

solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M=F,d_\perp\quad(\text{equivalently }M=rF\sin\phi)$. **2) Which is the correct diagram for B?** B. **3) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of the $100~\text{N}$ force?** The radius from the axis to the point of application is horizontal with length $l=0.08~\text{m}$, and the force is at $117^\circ$ from (+x). [ d_\perp=l\sin\phi=l\sin 117^\circ. ] **4) How would you find whether this moment is positive or negative?** Use the right-hand rule: with (r) to the right and the force having an upward component, the rotation is **counterclockwise** (\Rightarrow) $M>0$. **5) What is the moment of force of B about the axis?** [ d_\perp=0.08\sin117^\circ\approx 0.08(0.891)=0.0713~\text{m}, ] [ M=F,d_\perp=(100)(0.0713)\approx 7.13~\text{N m}. ] So the moment of B about the axis is **$+7.13~\text{N m}$** (counterclockwise).

full_question: If the magnitude of B is 173 N, what is the magnitude of A such that it will prevent rotation about the axis?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?
feedback_1: Uses the arm length, not the perpendicular distance.
feedback_2: Correct: moment equals force times perpendicular distance.
feedback_4: Velocity v is unrelated to static moment.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M=F,d_{\perp}\quad(\text{equivalently }M=rF\sin\phi)$. **2) Which is the correct diagram for B?** B. **3) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of B (the $173~\text{N}$ force)?** $d_{\perp,B}=l\sin\phi=l\sin117^\circ=(0.08)\sin117^\circ$. **4) What is the moment of force caused by B (the $173~\text{N}$ force)?** $ \begin{aligned} d_{\perp,B}&=0.08\sin117^\circ\approx 0.08(0.891)=0.0713~\text{m}, M_B&=F,d_{\perp,B}=173(0.0713)\approx 12.33~\text{N\cdot m}\quad(\text{CCW, }+). \end{aligned} $ **5) If A will prevent this rotation, it must cause a moment of force ** $M_A=-M_B$. **6) Which is the correct diagram for the moment caused by A?** A. **7) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of A?** $ \begin{aligned} d_{\perp,A}&=l\sin(90^\circ-40^\circ)=l\cos40^\circ &=(0.06)\cos40^\circ\approx 0.04596~\text{m}. \end{aligned} $ **8) What is the magnitude of A such that it will prevent rotation about the axis?** $ \begin{aligned} |M_A|&=|M_B|\Rightarrow A,d_{\perp,A}=12.33, A&=\dfrac{12.33}{0.04596}\approx 2.68\times10^2~\text{N}. \end{aligned} $ So, **$A\approx 268~\text{N}$**.

solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M=F,d_{\perp}\quad(\text{equivalently }M=rF\sin\phi)$. **2) Which is the correct diagram for B?** B. **3) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of B (the $173~\text{N}$ force)?** $d_{\perp,B}=l\sin\phi=l\sin117^\circ=(0.08)\sin117^\circ$. **4) What is the moment of force caused by B (the $173~\text{N}$ force)?** $ \begin{aligned} d_{\perp,B}&=0.08\sin117^\circ\approx 0.08(0.891)=0.0713~\text{m}, M_B&=F,d_{\perp,B}=173(0.0713)\approx 12.33~\text{N\cdot m}\quad(\text{CCW, }+). \end{aligned} $ **5) If A will prevent this rotation, it must cause a moment of force ** $M_A=-M_B$. **6) Which is the correct diagram for the moment caused by A?** A. **7) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of A?** $ \begin{aligned} d_{\perp,A}&=l\sin(90^\circ-40^\circ)=l\cos40^\circ &=(0.06)\cos40^\circ\approx 0.04596~\text{m}. \end{aligned} $ **8) What is the magnitude of A such that it will prevent rotation about the axis?** $ \begin{aligned} |M_A|&=|M_B|\Rightarrow A,d_{\perp,A}=12.33, A&=\dfrac{12.33}{0.04596}\approx 2.68\times10^2~\text{N}. \end{aligned} $ So, **$A\approx 268~\text{N}$**.

full_question: What is the net moment of force about the elbow?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?
feedback_1: 'a' is not the moment arm here.
feedback_2: $Correct: torque (moment) = force moment arm d.$
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M = F,d_\perp ;=; rF\sin\phi$. **2) Which is the correct diagram for the $100~\text{N}$ force?** A. **3) How would you find whether this moment of force is positive or negative?** Use the right-hand rule: force up **to the left** of the elbow causes clockwise rotation (\Rightarrow) $M<0$. **4) What is the moment of force caused by the $100~\text{N}$ force?** $d_{\perp,100}=0.042~\text{m};\Rightarrow; M_{100}=100(0.042)=4.2~\text{N m};(\text{clockwise})=;-4.2~\text{N m}.$ **5) Which is the correct diagram for the $600~\text{N}$ force?** D. **6) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M = F,d_\perp$. **7) How would you find whether this moment of force is positive or negative?** Force up **to the right** of the elbow gives counterclockwise rotation (\Rightarrow) $M>0$. **8) What is the moment of force caused by the $600~\text{N}$ force?** $d_{\perp,600}=0.020~\text{m};\Rightarrow; M_{600}=600(0.020)=12.0~\text{N m};(\text{CCW})=;+12.0~\text{N m}.$ **9) How would you find the total moment of force about the elbow?** $M_{\text{net}} = M_{100}+M_{600}.$ **10) What is the net moment of force about the elbow?** $ M_{\text{net}} = (-4.2) + (12.0) = +7.8~\text{N m} $ (counterclockwise).

full_question: How far away from the axis must a man ($F = 784.8 N$) on a teeter-totter sit if he wants to balance his daughter ($F = 225.63 N$) who is 2 m from the axis on the other end of the teeter-totter?
sub_question: Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?
feedback_1: $Correct: moment = force perpendicular distance to the axis.$
feedback_2: Notation Fa is ambiguous/incorrect here.
feedback_4: Fv is not a torque formula.
solution: **1) Which equation would you use to find the moment of force?** $M = F,d_\perp$ --- **2) Which is the correct diagram for the moment caused by the daughter?** A. --- **3) How would you find whether this moment of force is positive or negative?** Use the right-hand rule. A downward force on the **left** of the axis makes the board rotate **clockwise**, so with the CCW-positive convention: $M<0$. --- **4) What is the moment of force caused by the daughter?** $M_{\text{daughter}} = (225.63 \text{N})(2.0 \text{m}) = 451.26 \text{N m};(\text{clockwise}) = -451.26 \text{N m}.$ --- **5) If the man will prevent this rotation, he must cause a moment of force ** $M_{\text{man}} = +451.26 \text{N m};(\text{counterclockwise}).$ --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of the force caused by the man?** $d_{\text{man}}=\dfrac{M_{\text{man}}}{F_{\text{man}}}.$ --- **7) How far away from the axis must the man sit?** $ d_{\text{man}}=\frac{451.26}{784.8}=0.575 \text{m}. $ So, the man must sit **$0.575 \text{m}$** from the axis on his side to balance his daughter.

A downward force on the **left** of the axis makes the board rotate **clockwise**, so with the CCW-positive convention: $M<0$. --- **4) What is the moment of force caused by the daughter?** $M_{\text{daughter}} = (225.63 \text{N})(2.0 \text{m}) = 451.26 \text{N m};(\text{clockwise}) = -451.26 \text{N m}.$ --- **5) If the man will prevent this rotation, he must cause a moment of force ** $M_{\text{man}} = +451.26 \text{N m};(\text{counterclockwise}).$ --- **6) Which equation would you use to find the moment arm of the force caused by the man?** $d_{\text{man}}=\dfrac{M_{\text{man}}}{F_{\text{man}}}.$ --- **7) How far away from the axis must the man sit?** $ d_{\text{man}}=\frac{451.26}{784.8}=0.575 \text{m}. $ So, the man must sit **$0.575 \text{m}$** from the axis on his side to balance his daughter.

full_question: What is the moment of force of A about the axis?
sub_question: How would you find the distance between the axis and where the force acts?
feedback_2: Cross product finds torque, not distance.
solution: 1. **Distance from axis to force line:** $,l=\sqrt{(0.30)^2+(0.125)^2}=\sqrt{0.105625}\approx 0.325~\text{m},$ 2. **Correct diagram:** B. 3. **Distance (l):** $,l=0.325~\text{m},$ 4. **Angle (f):** $,f=\tan^{-1}!\left(\dfrac{0.125}{0.30}\right)\approx 22.6^\circ,$ 5. **Angle (q) (acute included angle):** $,q=60^\circ-f=60^\circ-22.6^\circ=37.4^\circ,$ 6. **Moment arm:** $,d_\perp=l\sin q,$ 7. **Moment of a force:** $,M=F,d_\perp=l,F\sin q,$ 8. **Numerics & sign (clockwise negative):** $,d_\perp=(0.325)\sin(37.4^\circ)\approx 0.197~\text{m},$ $,|M_A|=450\times 0.197\approx 88.8~\text{N\cdot m},$ $\boxed{M_A\approx -88.8~\text{N\cdot m}}$
